Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When French mathematician Laurent Schwartz
was in high school, he started to worry that he wasn't
smart enough to solve math problems. Maybe you know a similar feeling. You sit down to take a math test, and you feel your heart beat faster and your palms start to sweat. You get butterflies in your stomach,
and you can't concentrate. This phenomenon is called math anxiety, and if it happens to you,
you're not alone. Researchers think about 20% 
of the population suffers from it. Some psychologists even consider it
a diagnosable condition. But having mathematical anxiety doesn't
necessarily mean you're bad at math - not even close. Laurent Schwartz went on to win
the Fields Medal, the highest award in mathematics. People might think that they're anxious
about math because they're bad at it, but it's often the other way around. They're doing poorly in math
because they're anxious about it. Some psychologists think that's because math anxiety decreases 
a cognitive resource called working memory. That's the short-term memory system that helps you organize the information 
you need to complete a task. Worrying about being able to solve
math problems, or not doing well on a test, eats up working memory, leaving less of it available to tackle
the math itself. People can suddenly struggle
with even basic math skills, like arithmetic, 
that they've otherwise mastered. Academic anxiety certainly
isn't limited to math, but it does seem to happen much
more frequently, and cause more harm
in that subject. So why would that be? Researchers aren't yet sure, but some studies suggest that the way children are exposed
to math by their parents and teachers play a large part. If parents talk about math like
something challenging and unfamiliar, children can internalize that. Teachers with math anxiety are also
likely to spread it to their students. Pressure to solve problems quickly
dials up stress even more. And in some cultures, being good
at math is a sign of being smart in general. When the stakes are that high, it's not surprising 
that students are anxious. Even Maryam Mirzakhani, 
an influential mathematician who was the first woman to win
the Fields Medal, felt unconfident and lost interest
in mathematics because her math teacher in middle school
didn't think she was talented. So if you experience mathematical anxiety, what can you do? Relaxation techniques, 
like short breathing exercises, have improved test performance
in students with math anxiety. Writing down your worries can also help. This strategy may give you a chance
to reevaluate a stressful experience, freeing up working memory. And if you have the chance, physical activity, like a brisk walk,
deepens breathing and helps relieve muscle tension, preventing anxiety from building. You can also use your knowledge
about the brain to change your mindset. The brain is flexible, and the areas involved in math skills 
can always grow and develop. This is a psychological principle
called the growth mindset. Thinking of yourself as someone
who can grow and improve can actually help you grow and improve. If you're a teacher 
or parent of young children, try being playful with math
and focusing on the creative aspects. That can build the numerical skills that help students approach math 
with confidence later on. Importantly, you should give children
the time and space to work through their answers. And if you're an administrator, make sure your teachers 
have the positive attitudes and mathematical confidence necessary to inspire confidence 
in all of their students. Also, don't let anyone spread the myth that boys are innately 
better than girls at math. That is completely false. If you experience math anxiety, it may not help to just know 
that math anxiety exists. Or perhaps it's reassuring to put
a name to the problem. Regardless, if you take a look
around yourself, the odds are good that you'll see someone 
experiencing the same thing as you. Just remember that the anxiety is not
a reflection of your ability, but it is something you can conquer 
with time and awareness.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Math anxiety _______ the resources of working memory.
Options: A. Increases, B. Decreases, C. Does not affect, D. Improves
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the population is estimated to suffer from math anxiety? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. 40% Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between math anxiety and working memory? Options: A. Math anxiety increases working memory, allowing individuals to perform better in math., B. Math anxiety has no effect on working memory., C. Math anxiety decreases working memory, making it more difficult to perform math tasks., D. Working memory is not related to math anxiety. Correct Option: C
Question 3: A teacher wants to help her students build confidence in math. Which of the following approaches is most likely to be effective? Options: A. Emphasizing the importance of solving math problems quickly, B. Focusing on the creative aspects of math and providing students with time and space to work through their answers, C. Telling students that math is a challenging and unfamiliar subject, D. Encouraging students to compete with each other in math Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the psychological principle that suggests that the brain is flexible and can always grow and develop? Options: A. Fixed mindset, B. Growth mindset, C. Math anxiety, D. Working memory Correct Option: B
Question 5: Which of the following statements is TRUE about math anxiety? Options: A. Math anxiety is a reflection of an individual's ability to perform math tasks., B. Math anxiety is a diagnosable condition that affects only a small percentage of the population., C. Math anxiety can be conquered with time and awareness., D. Math anxiety is limited to math and does not affect other academic subjects. Correct Option: C
Question 6: A student is experiencing math anxiety and is struggling to focus during a math test. Which of the following strategies may help the student to relax and improve their performance? Options: A. Taking a break to watch TV, B. Engaging in physical activity, such as a brisk walk, C. Talking to a friend about their anxiety, D. Trying to solve the math problems more quickly Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the award won by Laurent Schwartz and Maryam Mirzakhani? Options: A. Nobel Prize, B. Fields Medal, C. Math Award, D. Science Prize Correct Option: B
Question 8: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math and students' math anxiety? Options: A. Parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math have no effect on students' math anxiety., B. Parents' and teachers' positive attitudes towards math can help to reduce students' math anxiety., C. Parents' and teachers' negative attitudes towards math can increase students' math anxiety., D. Parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math are the sole cause of students' math anxiety. Correct Option: C
Question 9: A researcher wants to study the causes of math anxiety. Which of the following research questions is most likely to guide their study? Options: A. What is the prevalence of math anxiety among students?, B. How does math anxiety affect students' performance in math?, C. What are the underlying causes of math anxiety, and how can it be prevented?, D. How does math anxiety compare to other forms of academic anxiety? Correct Option: C
Question 10: Which of the following statements is FALSE about math anxiety? Options: A. Math anxiety is a common phenomenon that affects many students., B. Math anxiety can be caused by parents' and teachers' negative attitudes towards math., C. Math anxiety is a reflection of an individual's ability to perform math tasks., D. Math anxiety can be conquered with time and awareness. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the relationship between math anxiety and working memory. The options provided in Question 2 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option (C) stating that math anxiety decreases working memory, making it more difficult to perform math tasks.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
When French mathematician Laurent Schwartz
was in high school, he started to worry that he wasn't
smart enough to solve math problems. Maybe you know a similar feeling. You sit down to take a math test, and you feel your heart beat faster and your palms start to sweat. You get butterflies in your stomach,
and you can't concentrate. This phenomenon is called math anxiety, and if it happens to you,
you're not alone. Researchers think about 20% 
of the population suffers from it. Some psychologists even consider it
a diagnosable condition. But having mathematical anxiety doesn't
necessarily mean you're bad at math - not even close. Laurent Schwartz went on to win
the Fields Medal, the highest award in mathematics. People might think that they're anxious
about math because they're bad at it, but it's often the other way around. They're doing poorly in math
because they're anxious about it. Some psychologists think that's because math anxiety decreases 
a cognitive resource called working memory. That's the short-term memory system that helps you organize the information 
you need to complete a task. Worrying about being able to solve
math problems, or not doing well on a test, eats up working memory, leaving less of it available to tackle
the math itself. People can suddenly struggle
with even basic math skills, like arithmetic, 
that they've otherwise mastered. Academic anxiety certainly
isn't limited to math, but it does seem to happen much
more frequently, and cause more harm
in that subject. So why would that be? Researchers aren't yet sure, but some studies suggest that the way children are exposed
to math by their parents and teachers play a large part. If parents talk about math like
something challenging and unfamiliar, children can internalize that. Teachers with math anxiety are also
likely to spread it to their students. Pressure to solve problems quickly
dials up stress even more. And in some cultures, being good
at math is a sign of being smart in general. When the stakes are that high, it's not surprising 
that students are anxious. Even Maryam Mirzakhani, 
an influential mathematician who was the first woman to win
the Fields Medal, felt unconfident and lost interest
in mathematics because her math teacher in middle school
didn't think she was talented. So if you experience mathematical anxiety, what can you do? Relaxation techniques, 
like short breathing exercises, have improved test performance
in students with math anxiety. Writing down your worries can also help. This strategy may give you a chance
to reevaluate a stressful experience, freeing up working memory. And if you have the chance, physical activity, like a brisk walk,
deepens breathing and helps relieve muscle tension, preventing anxiety from building. You can also use your knowledge
about the brain to change your mindset. The brain is flexible, and the areas involved in math skills 
can always grow and develop. This is a psychological principle
called the growth mindset. Thinking of yourself as someone
who can grow and improve can actually help you grow and improve. If you're a teacher 
or parent of young children, try being playful with math
and focusing on the creative aspects. That can build the numerical skills that help students approach math 
with confidence later on. Importantly, you should give children
the time and space to work through their answers. And if you're an administrator, make sure your teachers 
have the positive attitudes and mathematical confidence necessary to inspire confidence 
in all of their students. Also, don't let anyone spread the myth that boys are innately 
better than girls at math. That is completely false. If you experience math anxiety, it may not help to just know 
that math anxiety exists. Or perhaps it's reassuring to put
a name to the problem. Regardless, if you take a look
around yourself, the odds are good that you'll see someone 
experiencing the same thing as you. Just remember that the anxiety is not
a reflection of your ability, but it is something you can conquer 
with time and awareness.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Math anxiety may be the result of:
Options: A. The environment (i.e., parents, teachers, friends, society, etc.), B. Working hard on mathematical problems, C. Learning about the creative and beautiful aspects of mathematics, D. Relaxation techniques
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the population is estimated to suffer from math anxiety? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. 40% Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between math anxiety and working memory? Options: A. Math anxiety increases working memory, allowing individuals to perform better in math., B. Math anxiety has no effect on working memory., C. Math anxiety decreases working memory, making it more difficult to perform math tasks., D. Working memory is not related to math anxiety. Correct Option: C
Question 3: A teacher wants to help her students build confidence in math. Which of the following approaches is most likely to be effective? Options: A. Emphasizing the importance of solving math problems quickly, B. Focusing on the creative aspects of math and providing students with time and space to work through their answers, C. Telling students that math is a challenging and unfamiliar subject, D. Encouraging students to compete with each other in math Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the psychological principle that suggests that the brain is flexible and can always grow and develop? Options: A. Fixed mindset, B. Growth mindset, C. Math anxiety, D. Working memory Correct Option: B
Question 5: Which of the following statements is TRUE about math anxiety? Options: A. Math anxiety is a reflection of an individual's ability to perform math tasks., B. Math anxiety is a diagnosable condition that affects only a small percentage of the population., C. Math anxiety can be conquered with time and awareness., D. Math anxiety is limited to math and does not affect other academic subjects. Correct Option: C
Question 6: A student is experiencing math anxiety and is struggling to focus during a math test. Which of the following strategies may help the student to relax and improve their performance? Options: A. Taking a break to watch TV, B. Engaging in physical activity, such as a brisk walk, C. Talking to a friend about their anxiety, D. Trying to solve the math problems more quickly Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the award won by Laurent Schwartz and Maryam Mirzakhani? Options: A. Nobel Prize, B. Fields Medal, C. Math Award, D. Science Prize Correct Option: B
Question 8: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math and students' math anxiety? Options: A. Parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math have no effect on students' math anxiety., B. Parents' and teachers' positive attitudes towards math can help to reduce students' math anxiety., C. Parents' and teachers' negative attitudes towards math can increase students' math anxiety., D. Parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math are the sole cause of students' math anxiety. Correct Option: C
Question 9: A researcher wants to study the causes of math anxiety. Which of the following research questions is most likely to guide their study? Options: A. What is the prevalence of math anxiety among students?, B. How does math anxiety affect students' performance in math?, C. What are the underlying causes of math anxiety, and how can it be prevented?, D. How does math anxiety compare to other forms of academic anxiety? Correct Option: C
Question 10: Which of the following statements is FALSE about math anxiety? Options: A. Math anxiety is a common phenomenon that affects many students., B. Math anxiety can be caused by parents' and teachers' negative attitudes towards math., C. Math anxiety is a reflection of an individual's ability to perform math tasks., D. Math anxiety can be conquered with time and awareness. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions address the potential causes of math anxiety, specifically the role of environmental factors such as parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math. The correct options in both questions also align, suggesting that parents' and teachers' negative attitudes towards math can contribute to the development of math anxiety in students. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
When French mathematician Laurent Schwartz
was in high school, he started to worry that he wasn't
smart enough to solve math problems. Maybe you know a similar feeling. You sit down to take a math test, and you feel your heart beat faster and your palms start to sweat. You get butterflies in your stomach,
and you can't concentrate. This phenomenon is called math anxiety, and if it happens to you,
you're not alone. Researchers think about 20% 
of the population suffers from it. Some psychologists even consider it
a diagnosable condition. But having mathematical anxiety doesn't
necessarily mean you're bad at math - not even close. Laurent Schwartz went on to win
the Fields Medal, the highest award in mathematics. People might think that they're anxious
about math because they're bad at it, but it's often the other way around. They're doing poorly in math
because they're anxious about it. Some psychologists think that's because math anxiety decreases 
a cognitive resource called working memory. That's the short-term memory system that helps you organize the information 
you need to complete a task. Worrying about being able to solve
math problems, or not doing well on a test, eats up working memory, leaving less of it available to tackle
the math itself. People can suddenly struggle
with even basic math skills, like arithmetic, 
that they've otherwise mastered. Academic anxiety certainly
isn't limited to math, but it does seem to happen much
more frequently, and cause more harm
in that subject. So why would that be? Researchers aren't yet sure, but some studies suggest that the way children are exposed
to math by their parents and teachers play a large part. If parents talk about math like
something challenging and unfamiliar, children can internalize that. Teachers with math anxiety are also
likely to spread it to their students. Pressure to solve problems quickly
dials up stress even more. And in some cultures, being good
at math is a sign of being smart in general. When the stakes are that high, it's not surprising 
that students are anxious. Even Maryam Mirzakhani, 
an influential mathematician who was the first woman to win
the Fields Medal, felt unconfident and lost interest
in mathematics because her math teacher in middle school
didn't think she was talented. So if you experience mathematical anxiety, what can you do? Relaxation techniques, 
like short breathing exercises, have improved test performance
in students with math anxiety. Writing down your worries can also help. This strategy may give you a chance
to reevaluate a stressful experience, freeing up working memory. And if you have the chance, physical activity, like a brisk walk,
deepens breathing and helps relieve muscle tension, preventing anxiety from building. You can also use your knowledge
about the brain to change your mindset. The brain is flexible, and the areas involved in math skills 
can always grow and develop. This is a psychological principle
called the growth mindset. Thinking of yourself as someone
who can grow and improve can actually help you grow and improve. If you're a teacher 
or parent of young children, try being playful with math
and focusing on the creative aspects. That can build the numerical skills that help students approach math 
with confidence later on. Importantly, you should give children
the time and space to work through their answers. And if you're an administrator, make sure your teachers 
have the positive attitudes and mathematical confidence necessary to inspire confidence 
in all of their students. Also, don't let anyone spread the myth that boys are innately 
better than girls at math. That is completely false. If you experience math anxiety, it may not help to just know 
that math anxiety exists. Or perhaps it's reassuring to put
a name to the problem. Regardless, if you take a look
around yourself, the odds are good that you'll see someone 
experiencing the same thing as you. Just remember that the anxiety is not
a reflection of your ability, but it is something you can conquer 
with time and awareness.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Rare; good, B. Uncommon in schools; excellent, C. Widespread; poor, D. Not ignored; good
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
When French mathematician Laurent Schwartz
was in high school, he started to worry that he wasn't
smart enough to solve math problems. Maybe you know a similar feeling. You sit down to take a math test, and you feel your heart beat faster and your palms start to sweat. You get butterflies in your stomach,
and you can't concentrate. This phenomenon is called math anxiety, and if it happens to you,
you're not alone. Researchers think about 20% 
of the population suffers from it. Some psychologists even consider it
a diagnosable condition. But having mathematical anxiety doesn't
necessarily mean you're bad at math - not even close. Laurent Schwartz went on to win
the Fields Medal, the highest award in mathematics. People might think that they're anxious
about math because they're bad at it, but it's often the other way around. They're doing poorly in math
because they're anxious about it. Some psychologists think that's because math anxiety decreases 
a cognitive resource called working memory. That's the short-term memory system that helps you organize the information 
you need to complete a task. Worrying about being able to solve
math problems, or not doing well on a test, eats up working memory, leaving less of it available to tackle
the math itself. People can suddenly struggle
with even basic math skills, like arithmetic, 
that they've otherwise mastered. Academic anxiety certainly
isn't limited to math, but it does seem to happen much
more frequently, and cause more harm
in that subject. So why would that be? Researchers aren't yet sure, but some studies suggest that the way children are exposed
to math by their parents and teachers play a large part. If parents talk about math like
something challenging and unfamiliar, children can internalize that. Teachers with math anxiety are also
likely to spread it to their students. Pressure to solve problems quickly
dials up stress even more. And in some cultures, being good
at math is a sign of being smart in general. When the stakes are that high, it's not surprising 
that students are anxious. Even Maryam Mirzakhani, 
an influential mathematician who was the first woman to win
the Fields Medal, felt unconfident and lost interest
in mathematics because her math teacher in middle school
didn't think she was talented. So if you experience mathematical anxiety, what can you do? Relaxation techniques, 
like short breathing exercises, have improved test performance
in students with math anxiety. Writing down your worries can also help. This strategy may give you a chance
to reevaluate a stressful experience, freeing up working memory. And if you have the chance, physical activity, like a brisk walk,
deepens breathing and helps relieve muscle tension, preventing anxiety from building. You can also use your knowledge
about the brain to change your mindset. The brain is flexible, and the areas involved in math skills 
can always grow and develop. This is a psychological principle
called the growth mindset. Thinking of yourself as someone
who can grow and improve can actually help you grow and improve. If you're a teacher 
or parent of young children, try being playful with math
and focusing on the creative aspects. That can build the numerical skills that help students approach math 
with confidence later on. Importantly, you should give children
the time and space to work through their answers. And if you're an administrator, make sure your teachers 
have the positive attitudes and mathematical confidence necessary to inspire confidence 
in all of their students. Also, don't let anyone spread the myth that boys are innately 
better than girls at math. That is completely false. If you experience math anxiety, it may not help to just know 
that math anxiety exists. Or perhaps it's reassuring to put
a name to the problem. Regardless, if you take a look
around yourself, the odds are good that you'll see someone 
experiencing the same thing as you. Just remember that the anxiety is not
a reflection of your ability, but it is something you can conquer 
with time and awareness.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Math anxiety may hinder mathematical achievements since:
Options: A. It involves feelings of tension that interfere with the solving of mathematical problems, B. It may lead to avoidance from mathematical tasks, C. It includes low self confidence in one's ability to learn mathematics, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Is math anxiety a different name for "being bad at math"?
Options: A. Not necessarily: A person could perform better at math if he or she didn't suffer from math anxiety, B. Yes: Low math ability always results in math anxiety, C. Yes: The proof for this is that professional mathematicians never suffer from math anxiety, D. No: Math anxiety is not related to math performance
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the population is estimated to suffer from math anxiety? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. 40% Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between math anxiety and working memory? Options: A. Math anxiety is a diagnosable condition that affects only a small percentage of the population., C. Math anxiety can be conquered with time and awareness., D. Math anxiety is limited to math and does not affect other academic subjects. Correct Option: C
Question 6: A student is experiencing math anxiety and is struggling to focus during a math test. Which of the following strategies may help the student to relax and improve their performance? Options: A. Taking a break to watch TV, B. Engaging in physical activity, such as a brisk walk, C. Talking to a friend about their anxiety, D. Trying to solve the math problems more quickly Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the award won by Laurent Schwartz and Maryam Mirzakhani? Options: A. Nobel Prize, B. Fields Medal, C. Math Award, D. Science Prize Correct Option: B
Question 8: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math and students' math anxiety? Options: A. Parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math have no effect on students' math anxiety., B. Parents' and teachers' positive attitudes towards math can help to reduce students' math anxiety., C. Parents' and teachers' negative attitudes towards math can increase students' math anxiety., D. Parents' and teachers' attitudes towards math are the sole cause of students' math anxiety. Correct Option: C
Question 9: A researcher wants to study the causes of math anxiety. Which of the following research questions is most likely to guide their study? Options: A. What is the prevalence of math anxiety among students?, B. How does math anxiety affect students' performance in math?, C. What are the underlying causes of math anxiety, and how can it be prevented?, D. How does math anxiety compare to other forms of academic anxiety? Correct Option: C
Question 10: Which of the following statements is FALSE about math anxiety? Options: A. Math anxiety is a common phenomenon that affects many students., B. Math anxiety can be caused by parents' and teachers' negative attitudes towards math., C. Math anxiety is a reflection of an individual's ability to perform math tasks., D. Math anxiety can be conquered with time and awareness. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it addresses the relationship between math anxiety and an individual's ability to perform math tasks. The correct option, C, states that "Math anxiety can be conquered with time and awareness," which aligns with the ground truth MCQ's correct option, A, stating that math anxiety is not necessarily a reflection of being bad at math.

However, an even more similar question is Question 10, which has an option that directly addresses the relationship between math anxiety and an individual's ability to perform math tasks. The correct option in Question 10 is the one that states that the statement "Math anxiety is a reflection of an individual's ability to perform math tasks" is FALSE, which is similar to the ground truth MCQ's correct option.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Muhammad Ali spent years training
to become the greatest boxer the world had ever seen, but only moments to create
the shortest poem. Ali captivated Harvard's 
graduating class in 1975 with his message of unity and friendship. When he finished, 
the audience wanted more. They wanted a poem. Ali delivered what is considered
the shortest poem ever. "Me, we." Or is it "me, weeee"? No one's really sure. Regardless, if these two words are a poem,
then what exactly makes a poem a poem? Poets themselves have struggled
with this question, often using metaphors to approximate
a definition. Is a poem a little machine? A firework? An echo? A dream? Poetry generally has certain
recognizable characteristics. One - poems emphasize language's
musical qualities. This can be achieved through
rhyme, rhythm, and meter, from the sonnets of Shakepeare, to the odes of Confucius, to the Sanskrit Vedas. Two - poems use condensed language, like literature with all the water
wrung out of it. Three - poems often feature
intense feelings, from Rumi's spiritual poetry to Pablo Neruda's "Ode to an Onion." Poetry, like art itself, has a way
of challenging simple definitions. While the rhythmic patterns 
of the earliest poems were a way to remember stories
even before the advent of writing, a poem doesn't need to be lyrical. Reinhard Döhl's “Apfel” and Eugen Gomringer's "silencio" toe the line between visual art
and poetry. Meanwhile, E.E. Cummings wrote poems
whose shapes were as important as the words themselves, in this case amplifying the sad loneliness
of a single leaf falling through space. If the visual nature of poetry
faded into the background, perhaps we'd be left with music, and that's an area that people
love to debate. Are songs poems? Many don't regard songwriters as poets
in a literary sense, but lyrics from artists like Paul Simon, Bob Dylan, and Tupac Shakur often hold up even without the music. In rap, poet elements like rhyme,
rhythm, and imagery are inseparable from the form. Take this lyric from the Notorious B.I.G. "I can hear sweat trickling 
down your cheek Your heartbeat sound 
like Sasquatch feet Thundering, shaking the concrete." So far, all the examples we've seen
have had line breaks. We can even imagine the two words
of Ali's poem organizing in the air - Me, We. Poetry has a shape 
that we can usually recognize. Its line breaks help readers navigate
the rhythms of a poem. But what if those line breaks disappeared? Would it lose its essence as a poem? Maybe not. Enter the prose poem. Prose poems use vivid images
and wordplay but are formatted like paragraphs. When we look at poetry less as a form
and more as a concept, we can see the poetic all around us: spiritual hymns, the speeches of orators like
Martin Luther King, Jr., JFK, and Winston Churchill, and surprising places like social media. In 2010, journalist Joanna Smith tweeted
updates from the earthquake in Haiti. "Was in b-room getting dressed
when heard my name. Tremor. Ran outside through sliding door. All still now. Safe. Roosters crowing." Smith uses language in a way
that is powerful, direct, and filled with vivid images. Compare her language to a haiku, the ancient Japanese poetic form 
that emphasizes bursts of brief intensity with just three lines of five, 
seven, and five syllables. The waters of poetry run wide and deep. Poetry has evolved over time, and perhaps now more than ever, the line between poetry, 
prose, song, and visual art has blurred. However, one thing has not changed. The word poetry actually began
in verb form, coming from the ancient Greek poiesis,
which means to create. Poets, like craftsman, still work with
the raw materials of the world to forge new understandings and comment on what it is to be human
in a way only humans can. Dartmouth researchers tested this idea
by asking robots to pen poetry. A panel of judges sorted 
through stacks of sonnets to see if they could distinguish those
made by man and machine. You may be happy to know that while
scientists have successfully used artificial intelligence 
in manufacturing, medicine, and even journalism, poetry is a different story. The robots were caught red-handed
100% of the time.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is not a characteristic traditionally associated with poetry?
Options: A. Rhythm, B. Condensed language, C. Intense feelings, D. Paragraphs
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is considered the shortest poem ever, as delivered by Muhammad Ali in 1975? Options: A. "Me, myself, and I", B. "Me, we", C. "We, us", D. "I, you" Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what are three recognizable characteristics of poetry? Options: A. Emphasis on language's musical qualities, use of complex vocabulary, and lack of intense feelings, B. Emphasis on language's musical qualities, use of condensed language, and presence of intense feelings, C. Use of simple vocabulary, lack of rhythm, and presence of intense feelings, D. Use of complex vocabulary, emphasis on language's musical qualities, and lack of intense feelings Correct Option: B
Question 3: Which poet's work is mentioned as an example of visual poetry, where the shape of the poem is as important as the words themselves? Options: A. E.E. Cummings, B. Reinhard Döhl, C. Eugen Gomringer, D. Pablo Neruda Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name of the ancient Japanese poetic form that emphasizes bursts of brief intensity with just three lines of five, seven, and five syllables? Options: A. Haiku, B. Sonnet, C. Ode, D. Free verse Correct Option: A
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the origin of the word "poetry"? Options: A. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to read", B. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to create", C. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to write", D. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to speak" Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main difference between a traditional poem and a prose poem? Options: A. A traditional poem uses vivid images, while a prose poem does not., B. A traditional poem has a specific rhyme scheme, while a prose poem does not., C. A traditional poem has line breaks, while a prose poem is formatted like a paragraph., D. A traditional poem is short, while a prose poem is long. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the Dartmouth researchers test the idea that poetry is a unique human creation? Options: A. By asking humans to pen poetry and comparing it to existing poems, B. By asking robots to pen poetry and having a panel of judges distinguish between human and machine-created poems, C. By analyzing the language patterns of human and machine-created poems, D. By conducting a survey on the definition of poetry Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the result of the experiment conducted by the Dartmouth researchers? Options: A. The robots were able to create poems that were indistinguishable from human-created poems., B. The robots were caught 50% of the time., C. The robots were caught 100% of the time., D. The results were inconclusive. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Analyze the following statement: "Poetry has evolved over time, and perhaps now more than ever, the line between poetry, prose, song, and visual art has blurred." What does this statement suggest about the nature of poetry? Options: A. Poetry is a fixed and traditional art form., B. Poetry is a dynamic and constantly evolving art form., C. Poetry is only related to literature and not to other art forms., D. Poetry is a separate entity from prose, song, and visual art. Correct Option: B
Question 10: Evaluate the following statement: "Poets, like craftsmen, still work with the raw materials of the world to forge new understandings and comment on what it is to be human in a way only humans can." What does this statement suggest about the role of poets in society? Options: A. Poets are merely entertainers who create art for art's sake., B. Poets are craftsmen who use their skills to create something new and meaningful., C. Poets are only concerned with expressing their own emotions and experiences., D. Poets are unnecessary in today's society. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. However, it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the characteristics of poetry rather than which one is not associated with poetry.

A more suitable match would be Question 6, which asks about the main difference between a traditional poem and a prose poem. One of the options (C) mentions line breaks, which is related to the ground truth MCQ's correct answer (D. Paragraphs). However, it still does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would choose Question 6, but with the understanding that it is not a perfect match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Muhammad Ali spent years training
to become the greatest boxer the world had ever seen, but only moments to create
the shortest poem. Ali captivated Harvard's 
graduating class in 1975 with his message of unity and friendship. When he finished, 
the audience wanted more. They wanted a poem. Ali delivered what is considered
the shortest poem ever. "Me, we." Or is it "me, weeee"? No one's really sure. Regardless, if these two words are a poem,
then what exactly makes a poem a poem? Poets themselves have struggled
with this question, often using metaphors to approximate
a definition. Is a poem a little machine? A firework? An echo? A dream? Poetry generally has certain
recognizable characteristics. One - poems emphasize language's
musical qualities. This can be achieved through
rhyme, rhythm, and meter, from the sonnets of Shakepeare, to the odes of Confucius, to the Sanskrit Vedas. Two - poems use condensed language, like literature with all the water
wrung out of it. Three - poems often feature
intense feelings, from Rumi's spiritual poetry to Pablo Neruda's "Ode to an Onion." Poetry, like art itself, has a way
of challenging simple definitions. While the rhythmic patterns 
of the earliest poems were a way to remember stories
even before the advent of writing, a poem doesn't need to be lyrical. Reinhard Döhl's “Apfel” and Eugen Gomringer's "silencio" toe the line between visual art
and poetry. Meanwhile, E.E. Cummings wrote poems
whose shapes were as important as the words themselves, in this case amplifying the sad loneliness
of a single leaf falling through space. If the visual nature of poetry
faded into the background, perhaps we'd be left with music, and that's an area that people
love to debate. Are songs poems? Many don't regard songwriters as poets
in a literary sense, but lyrics from artists like Paul Simon, Bob Dylan, and Tupac Shakur often hold up even without the music. In rap, poet elements like rhyme,
rhythm, and imagery are inseparable from the form. Take this lyric from the Notorious B.I.G. "I can hear sweat trickling 
down your cheek Your heartbeat sound 
like Sasquatch feet Thundering, shaking the concrete." So far, all the examples we've seen
have had line breaks. We can even imagine the two words
of Ali's poem organizing in the air - Me, We. Poetry has a shape 
that we can usually recognize. Its line breaks help readers navigate
the rhythms of a poem. But what if those line breaks disappeared? Would it lose its essence as a poem? Maybe not. Enter the prose poem. Prose poems use vivid images
and wordplay but are formatted like paragraphs. When we look at poetry less as a form
and more as a concept, we can see the poetic all around us: spiritual hymns, the speeches of orators like
Martin Luther King, Jr., JFK, and Winston Churchill, and surprising places like social media. In 2010, journalist Joanna Smith tweeted
updates from the earthquake in Haiti. "Was in b-room getting dressed
when heard my name. Tremor. Ran outside through sliding door. All still now. Safe. Roosters crowing." Smith uses language in a way
that is powerful, direct, and filled with vivid images. Compare her language to a haiku, the ancient Japanese poetic form 
that emphasizes bursts of brief intensity with just three lines of five, 
seven, and five syllables. The waters of poetry run wide and deep. Poetry has evolved over time, and perhaps now more than ever, the line between poetry, 
prose, song, and visual art has blurred. However, one thing has not changed. The word poetry actually began
in verb form, coming from the ancient Greek poiesis,
which means to create. Poets, like craftsman, still work with
the raw materials of the world to forge new understandings and comment on what it is to be human
in a way only humans can. Dartmouth researchers tested this idea
by asking robots to pen poetry. A panel of judges sorted 
through stacks of sonnets to see if they could distinguish those
made by man and machine. You may be happy to know that while
scientists have successfully used artificial intelligence 
in manufacturing, medicine, and even journalism, poetry is a different story. The robots were caught red-handed
100% of the time.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The word poetry comes from the Greek “poiesis.” What does this word mean?
Options: A. To rhyme, B. To write, C. To make, D. To think
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is considered the shortest poem ever, as delivered by Muhammad Ali in 1975? Options: A. "Me, myself, and I", B. "Me, we", C. "We, us", D. "I, you" Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what are three recognizable characteristics of poetry? Options: A. Emphasis on language's musical qualities, use of complex vocabulary, and lack of intense feelings, B. Emphasis on language's musical qualities, use of condensed language, and presence of intense feelings, C. Use of simple vocabulary, lack of rhythm, and presence of intense feelings, D. Use of complex vocabulary, emphasis on language's musical qualities, and lack of intense feelings Correct Option: B
Question 3: Which poet's work is mentioned as an example of visual poetry, where the shape of the poem is as important as the words themselves? Options: A. E.E. Cummings, B. Reinhard Döhl, C. Eugen Gomringer, D. Pablo Neruda Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name of the ancient Japanese poetic form that emphasizes bursts of brief intensity with just three lines of five, seven, and five syllables? Options: A. Haiku, B. Sonnet, C. Ode, D. Free verse Correct Option: A
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the origin of the word "poetry"? Options: A. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to read", B. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to create", C. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to write", D. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to speak" Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main difference between a traditional poem and a prose poem? Options: A. A traditional poem uses vivid images, while a prose poem does not., B. A traditional poem has a specific rhyme scheme, while a prose poem does not., C. A traditional poem has line breaks, while a prose poem is formatted like a paragraph., D. A traditional poem is short, while a prose poem is long. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the Dartmouth researchers test the idea that poetry is a unique human creation? Options: A. By asking humans to pen poetry and comparing it to existing poems, B. By asking robots to pen poetry and having a panel of judges distinguish between human and machine-created poems, C. By analyzing the language patterns of human and machine-created poems, D. By conducting a survey on the definition of poetry Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the result of the experiment conducted by the Dartmouth researchers? Options: A. The robots were able to create poems that were indistinguishable from human-created poems., B. The robots were caught 50% of the time., C. The robots were caught 100% of the time., D. The results were inconclusive. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Analyze the following statement: "Poetry has evolved over time, and perhaps now more than ever, the line between poetry, prose, song, and visual art has blurred." What does this statement suggest about the nature of poetry? Options: A. Poetry is a fixed and traditional art form., B. Poetry is a dynamic and constantly evolving art form., C. Poetry is only related to literature and not to other art forms., D. Poetry is a separate entity from prose, song, and visual art. Correct Option: B
Question 10: Evaluate the following statement: "Poets, like craftsmen, still work with the raw materials of the world to forge new understandings and comment on what it is to be human in a way only humans can." What does this statement suggest about the role of poets in society? Options: A. Poets are merely entertainers who create art for art's sake., B. Poets are craftsmen who use their skills to create something new and meaningful., C. Poets are only concerned with expressing their own emotions and experiences., D. Poets are unnecessary in today's society. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (origin of the word "poetry"), options (similar answer choices, including the correct answer "to create"), and content (reference to the ancient Greek word "poiesis"). 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Muhammad Ali spent years training
to become the greatest boxer the world had ever seen, but only moments to create
the shortest poem. Ali captivated Harvard's 
graduating class in 1975 with his message of unity and friendship. When he finished, 
the audience wanted more. They wanted a poem. Ali delivered what is considered
the shortest poem ever. "Me, we." Or is it "me, weeee"? No one's really sure. Regardless, if these two words are a poem,
then what exactly makes a poem a poem? Poets themselves have struggled
with this question, often using metaphors to approximate
a definition. Is a poem a little machine? A firework? An echo? A dream? Poetry generally has certain
recognizable characteristics. One - poems emphasize language's
musical qualities. This can be achieved through
rhyme, rhythm, and meter, from the sonnets of Shakepeare, to the odes of Confucius, to the Sanskrit Vedas. Two - poems use condensed language, like literature with all the water
wrung out of it. Three - poems often feature
intense feelings, from Rumi's spiritual poetry to Pablo Neruda's "Ode to an Onion." Poetry, like art itself, has a way
of challenging simple definitions. While the rhythmic patterns 
of the earliest poems were a way to remember stories
even before the advent of writing, a poem doesn't need to be lyrical. Reinhard Döhl's “Apfel” and Eugen Gomringer's "silencio" toe the line between visual art
and poetry. Meanwhile, E.E. Cummings wrote poems
whose shapes were as important as the words themselves, in this case amplifying the sad loneliness
of a single leaf falling through space. If the visual nature of poetry
faded into the background, perhaps we'd be left with music, and that's an area that people
love to debate. Are songs poems? Many don't regard songwriters as poets
in a literary sense, but lyrics from artists like Paul Simon, Bob Dylan, and Tupac Shakur often hold up even without the music. In rap, poet elements like rhyme,
rhythm, and imagery are inseparable from the form. Take this lyric from the Notorious B.I.G. "I can hear sweat trickling 
down your cheek Your heartbeat sound 
like Sasquatch feet Thundering, shaking the concrete." So far, all the examples we've seen
have had line breaks. We can even imagine the two words
of Ali's poem organizing in the air - Me, We. Poetry has a shape 
that we can usually recognize. Its line breaks help readers navigate
the rhythms of a poem. But what if those line breaks disappeared? Would it lose its essence as a poem? Maybe not. Enter the prose poem. Prose poems use vivid images
and wordplay but are formatted like paragraphs. When we look at poetry less as a form
and more as a concept, we can see the poetic all around us: spiritual hymns, the speeches of orators like
Martin Luther King, Jr., JFK, and Winston Churchill, and surprising places like social media. In 2010, journalist Joanna Smith tweeted
updates from the earthquake in Haiti. "Was in b-room getting dressed
when heard my name. Tremor. Ran outside through sliding door. All still now. Safe. Roosters crowing." Smith uses language in a way
that is powerful, direct, and filled with vivid images. Compare her language to a haiku, the ancient Japanese poetic form 
that emphasizes bursts of brief intensity with just three lines of five, 
seven, and five syllables. The waters of poetry run wide and deep. Poetry has evolved over time, and perhaps now more than ever, the line between poetry, 
prose, song, and visual art has blurred. However, one thing has not changed. The word poetry actually began
in verb form, coming from the ancient Greek poiesis,
which means to create. Poets, like craftsman, still work with
the raw materials of the world to forge new understandings and comment on what it is to be human
in a way only humans can. Dartmouth researchers tested this idea
by asking robots to pen poetry. A panel of judges sorted 
through stacks of sonnets to see if they could distinguish those
made by man and machine. You may be happy to know that while
scientists have successfully used artificial intelligence 
in manufacturing, medicine, and even journalism, poetry is a different story. The robots were caught red-handed
100% of the time.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a haiku?
Options: A. A type of poem that consists of three lines of 5, 7, and 5 syllables, B. A type of poem that consists of three lines of 7, 5, and 5 syllables, C. A type of poem that rhymes and is often sung, D. A type of poem that creates a shape or picture that adds to its meaning
Correct Option: A

Question 4: What is the name of the ancient Japanese poetic form that emphasizes bursts of brief intensity with just three lines of five, seven, and five syllables? Options: A. Haiku, B. Sonnet, C. Ode, D. Free verse Correct Option: A

From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to create", C. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to write", D. From the ancient Greek word "poiesis," meaning "to speak" Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the main difference between a traditional poem and a prose poem? Options: A. A traditional poem uses vivid images, while a prose poem does not., B. A traditional poem has a specific rhyme scheme, while a prose poem does not., C. A traditional poem has line breaks, while a prose poem is formatted like a paragraph., D. A traditional poem is short, while a prose poem is long. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the Dartmouth researchers test the idea that poetry is a unique human creation? Options: A. By asking humans to pen poetry and comparing it to existing poems, B. By asking robots to pen poetry and having a panel of judges distinguish between human and machine-created poems, C. By analyzing the language patterns of human and machine-created poems, D. By conducting a survey on the definition of poetry Correct Option: B

The robots were caught 50% of the time., C. The robots were caught 100% of the time., D. The results were inconclusive. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Analyze the following statement: "Poetry has evolved over time, and perhaps now more than ever, the line between poetry, prose, song, and visual art has blurred." What does this statement suggest about the nature of poetry? Options: A. Poetry is a fixed and traditional art form., B. Poetry is a dynamic and constantly evolving art form., C. Poetry is only related to literature and not to other art forms., D. Poetry is a separate entity from prose, song, and visual art. Correct Option: B
Question 10: Evaluate the following statement: "Poets, like craftsmen, still work with the raw materials of the world to forge new understandings and comment on what it is to be human in a way only humans can." What does this statement suggest about the role of poets in society? Options: A. Poets are merely entertainers who create art for art's sake., B. Poets are craftsmen who use their skills to create something new and meaningful., C. Poets are only concerned with expressing their own emotions and experiences., D. Poets are unnecessary in today's society. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to define what a haiku is. The options provided in Question 4 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option being the definition of a haiku as an ancient Japanese poetic form with three lines of five, seven, and five syllables.

**Transcript**:
Muhammad Ali spent years training
to become the greatest boxer the world had ever seen, but only moments to create
the shortest poem. Ali captivated Harvard's 
graduating class in 1975 with his message of unity and friendship. When he finished, 
the audience wanted more. They wanted a poem. Ali delivered what is considered
the shortest poem ever. "Me, we." Or is it "me, weeee"? No one's really sure. Regardless, if these two words are a poem,
then what exactly makes a poem a poem? Poets themselves have struggled
with this question, often using metaphors to approximate
a definition. Is a poem a little machine? A firework? An echo? A dream? Poetry generally has certain
recognizable characteristics. One - poems emphasize language's
musical qualities. This can be achieved through
rhyme, rhythm, and meter, from the sonnets of Shakepeare, to the odes of Confucius, to the Sanskrit Vedas. Two - poems use condensed language, like literature with all the water
wrung out of it. Three - poems often feature
intense feelings, from Rumi's spiritual poetry to Pablo Neruda's "Ode to an Onion." Poetry, like art itself, has a way
of challenging simple definitions. While the rhythmic patterns 
of the earliest poems were a way to remember stories
even before the advent of writing, a poem doesn't need to be lyrical. Reinhard Döhl's “Apfel” and Eugen Gomringer's "silencio" toe the line between visual art
and poetry. Meanwhile, E.E. Cummings wrote poems
whose shapes were as important as the words themselves, in this case amplifying the sad loneliness
of a single leaf falling through space. If the visual nature of poetry
faded into the background, perhaps we'd be left with music, and that's an area that people
love to debate. Are songs poems? Many don't regard songwriters as poets
in a literary sense, but lyrics from artists like Paul Simon, Bob Dylan, and Tupac Shakur often hold up even without the music. In rap, poet elements like rhyme,
rhythm, and imagery are inseparable from the form. Take this lyric from the Notorious B.I.G. "I can hear sweat trickling 
down your cheek Your heartbeat sound 
like Sasquatch feet Thundering, shaking the concrete." So far, all the examples we've seen
have had line breaks. We can even imagine the two words
of Ali's poem organizing in the air - Me, We. Poetry has a shape 
that we can usually recognize. Its line breaks help readers navigate
the rhythms of a poem. But what if those line breaks disappeared? Would it lose its essence as a poem? Maybe not. Enter the prose poem. Prose poems use vivid images
and wordplay but are formatted like paragraphs. When we look at poetry less as a form
and more as a concept, we can see the poetic all around us: spiritual hymns, the speeches of orators like
Martin Luther King, Jr., JFK, and Winston Churchill, and surprising places like social media. In 2010, journalist Joanna Smith tweeted
updates from the earthquake in Haiti. "Was in b-room getting dressed
when heard my name. Tremor. Ran outside through sliding door. All still now. Safe. Roosters crowing." Smith uses language in a way
that is powerful, direct, and filled with vivid images. Compare her language to a haiku, the ancient Japanese poetic form 
that emphasizes bursts of brief intensity with just three lines of five, 
seven, and five syllables. The waters of poetry run wide and deep. Poetry has evolved over time, and perhaps now more than ever, the line between poetry, 
prose, song, and visual art has blurred. However, one thing has not changed. The word poetry actually began
in verb form, coming from the ancient Greek poiesis,
which means to create. Poets, like craftsman, still work with
the raw materials of the world to forge new understandings and comment on what it is to be human
in a way only humans can. Dartmouth researchers tested this idea
by asking robots to pen poetry. A panel of judges sorted 
through stacks of sonnets to see if they could distinguish those
made by man and machine. You may be happy to know that while
scientists have successfully used artificial intelligence 
in manufacturing, medicine, and even journalism, poetry is a different story. The robots were caught red-handed
100% of the time.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does Reinhard Dohl’s “Apfel” have in common with e.e. cummings’ “l(a)”?
Options: A. The musical quality of language is emphasized in both poems, B. The visual arrangement of words is important to the meaning of each poem, C. Both are written in English, D. Both are considered free verse poetry
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you can't imagine
life without chocolate, you're lucky you weren't born before
the 16th century. Until then, chocolate only existed
in Mesoamerica in a form quite different 
from what we know. As far back as 1900 BCE, the people of that region had learned
to prepare the beans of the native cacao tree. The earliest records tell us the beans
were ground and mixed with cornmeal
and chili peppers to create a drink - not a relaxing cup of hot cocoa, but a bitter, invigorating concoction
frothing with foam. And if you thought we make
a big deal about chocolate today, the Mesoamericans had us beat. They believed that cacao
was a heavenly food gifted to humans
by a feathered serpent god, known to the Maya as Kukulkan and to the Aztecs as Quetzalcoatl. Aztecs used cacao beans as currency and drank chocolate at royal feasts, gave it to soldiers as a reward
for success in battle, and used it in rituals. The first transatlantic
chocolate encounter occurred in 1519 when Hernán Cortés visited
the court of Moctezuma at Tenochtitlan. As recorded by Cortés's lieutenant, the king had 50 jugs of the drink
brought out and poured into golden cups. When the colonists returned with shipments
of the strange new bean, missionaries' salacious accounts
of native customs gave it a reputation as an aphrodisiac. At first, its bitter taste made it
suitable as a medicine for ailments, like upset stomachs, but sweetening it with honey,
sugar, or vanilla quickly made chocolate a popular delicacy
in the Spanish court. And soon, no aristocratic home was
complete without dedicated chocolate ware. The fashionable drink was difficult
and time consuming to produce on a large scale. That involved using plantations
and imported slave labor in the Caribbean and 
on islands off the coast of Africa. The world of chocolate would change
forever in 1828 with the introduction of the cocoa press
by Coenraad van Houten of Amsterdam. Van Houten's invention could separate
the cocoa's natural fat, or cocoa butter. This left a powder that could be mixed
into a drinkable solution or recombined with the cocoa butter to create the solid chocolate
we know today. Not long after, a Swiss chocolatier
named Daniel Peter added powdered milk to the mix, thus inventing milk chocolate. By the 20th century, chocolate
was no longer an elite luxury but had become a treat for the public. Meeting the massive demand required
more cultivation of cocoa, which can only grow near the equator. Now, instead of African slaves 
being shipped to South American cocoa plantations, cocoa production itself would shift
to West Africa with Cote d'Ivoire providing two-fifths
of the world's cocoa as of 2015. Yet along with the growth
of the industry, there have been horrific abuses
of human rights. Many of the plantations throughout
West Africa, which supply Western companies, use slave and child labor, with an estimation of more than
2 million children affected. This is a complex problem
that persists despite efforts from major chocolate
companies to partner with African nations to reduce child 
and indentured labor practices. Today, chocolate has established itself
in the rituals of our modern culture. Due to its colonial association with
native cultures, combined with the power of advertising, chocolate retains an aura
of something sensual, decadent, and forbidden. Yet knowing more about its fascinating
and often cruel history, as well as its production today, tells us where 
these associations originate and what they hide. So as you unwrap 
your next bar of chocolate, take a moment to consider that
not everything about chocolate is sweet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The first transatlantic chocolate encounter occurred in:
Options: A. 1509, B. 1513, C. 1519, D. 1527
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what century did chocolate start to exist outside of Mesoamerica? Options: A. 15th century, B. 16th century, C. 17th century, D. 18th century Correct Option: B
Question 2: How did the Mesoamericans prepare the beans of the native cacao tree? Options: A. By grinding and mixing them with sugar and milk, B. By grinding and mixing them with cornmeal and chili peppers, C. By boiling and mixing them with honey and vanilla, D. By steaming and mixing them with water and salt Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the significance of cacao beans in Aztec culture? Options: A. They were used as a form of punishment for soldiers, B. They were used as currency and a reward for soldiers, C. They were used as a form of medicine for ailments, D. They were used as a form of decoration for royal feasts Correct Option: B
Question 4: What event in 1519 marked the first transatlantic chocolate encounter? Options: A. Hernán Cortés's visit to the court of Moctezuma at Tenochtitlan, B. The introduction of the cocoa press by Coenraad van Houten, C. The invention of milk chocolate by Daniel Peter, D. The establishment of the first chocolate plantation in West Africa Correct Option: A
Question 5: How did the reputation of chocolate change after the colonists returned with shipments of the bean? Options: A. It became known as a medicine for ailments, B. It became known as a popular delicacy in the Spanish court, C. It became known as an aphrodisiac due to missionaries' salacious accounts, D. It became known as a bitter and invigorating concoction Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the impact of Coenraad van Houten's invention of the cocoa press in 1828? Options: A. It made chocolate production more time-consuming and labor-intensive, B. It made chocolate production more expensive and exclusive, C. It made chocolate production easier and more widespread, D. It made chocolate production more dependent on slave labor Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is a major issue that persists in the chocolate industry today? Options: A. The use of artificial flavorings and preservatives, B. The exploitation of cocoa farmers and producers, C. The use of slave and child labor in West African plantations, D. The environmental impact of cocoa cultivation Correct Option: C
Question 8: How has the association of chocolate with native cultures and advertising contributed to its modern cultural significance? Options: A. It has created a perception of chocolate as a healthy and sustainable food, B. It has created a perception of chocolate as a sensual, decadent, and forbidden treat, C. It has created a perception of chocolate as a cheap and accessible luxury, D. It has created a perception of chocolate as a traditional and cultural staple Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the estimated number of children affected by slave and child labor in West African cocoa plantations? Options: A. Over 1 million, B. Over 2 million, C. Over 5 million, D. Over 10 million Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the author's intention in highlighting the complex history and production of chocolate? Options: A. To promote the consumption of chocolate as a luxury good, B. To raise awareness about the social and environmental issues surrounding chocolate production, C. To celebrate the cultural significance of chocolate in modern society, D. To provide a historical account of chocolate's origins and evolution Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you can't imagine
life without chocolate, you're lucky you weren't born before
the 16th century. Until then, chocolate only existed
in Mesoamerica in a form quite different 
from what we know. As far back as 1900 BCE, the people of that region had learned
to prepare the beans of the native cacao tree. The earliest records tell us the beans
were ground and mixed with cornmeal
and chili peppers to create a drink - not a relaxing cup of hot cocoa, but a bitter, invigorating concoction
frothing with foam. And if you thought we make
a big deal about chocolate today, the Mesoamericans had us beat. They believed that cacao
was a heavenly food gifted to humans
by a feathered serpent god, known to the Maya as Kukulkan and to the Aztecs as Quetzalcoatl. Aztecs used cacao beans as currency and drank chocolate at royal feasts, gave it to soldiers as a reward
for success in battle, and used it in rituals. The first transatlantic
chocolate encounter occurred in 1519 when Hernán Cortés visited
the court of Moctezuma at Tenochtitlan. As recorded by Cortés's lieutenant, the king had 50 jugs of the drink
brought out and poured into golden cups. When the colonists returned with shipments
of the strange new bean, missionaries' salacious accounts
of native customs gave it a reputation as an aphrodisiac. At first, its bitter taste made it
suitable as a medicine for ailments, like upset stomachs, but sweetening it with honey,
sugar, or vanilla quickly made chocolate a popular delicacy
in the Spanish court. And soon, no aristocratic home was
complete without dedicated chocolate ware. The fashionable drink was difficult
and time consuming to produce on a large scale. That involved using plantations
and imported slave labor in the Caribbean and 
on islands off the coast of Africa. The world of chocolate would change
forever in 1828 with the introduction of the cocoa press
by Coenraad van Houten of Amsterdam. Van Houten's invention could separate
the cocoa's natural fat, or cocoa butter. This left a powder that could be mixed
into a drinkable solution or recombined with the cocoa butter to create the solid chocolate
we know today. Not long after, a Swiss chocolatier
named Daniel Peter added powdered milk to the mix, thus inventing milk chocolate. By the 20th century, chocolate
was no longer an elite luxury but had become a treat for the public. Meeting the massive demand required
more cultivation of cocoa, which can only grow near the equator. Now, instead of African slaves 
being shipped to South American cocoa plantations, cocoa production itself would shift
to West Africa with Cote d'Ivoire providing two-fifths
of the world's cocoa as of 2015. Yet along with the growth
of the industry, there have been horrific abuses
of human rights. Many of the plantations throughout
West Africa, which supply Western companies, use slave and child labor, with an estimation of more than
2 million children affected. This is a complex problem
that persists despite efforts from major chocolate
companies to partner with African nations to reduce child 
and indentured labor practices. Today, chocolate has established itself
in the rituals of our modern culture. Due to its colonial association with
native cultures, combined with the power of advertising, chocolate retains an aura
of something sensual, decadent, and forbidden. Yet knowing more about its fascinating
and often cruel history, as well as its production today, tells us where 
these associations originate and what they hide. So as you unwrap 
your next bar of chocolate, take a moment to consider that
not everything about chocolate is sweet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Chocolate has a long history of being linked to love. ______ drank cocoa before visiting with his wives.
Options: A. King Henry VIII, B. Montezuma, C. Zeus, D. King Louis VIII
Correct Option: B

Question 8: How has the association of chocolate with native cultures and advertising contributed to its modern cultural significance? Options: A. It has created a perception of chocolate as a healthy and sustainable food, B. It has created a perception of chocolate as a sensual, decadent, and forbidden treat, C. It has created a perception of chocolate as a cheap and accessible luxury, D. It has created a perception of chocolate as a traditional and cultural staple Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the estimated number of children affected by slave and child labor in West African cocoa plantations? Options: A. Over 1 million, B. Over 2 million, C. Over 5 million, D. Over 10 million Correct Option: B

To raise awareness about the social and environmental issues surrounding chocolate production, C. To celebrate the cultural significance of chocolate in modern society, D. To provide a historical account of chocolate's origins and evolution Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
If you can't imagine
life without chocolate, you're lucky you weren't born before
the 16th century. Until then, chocolate only existed
in Mesoamerica in a form quite different 
from what we know. As far back as 1900 BCE, the people of that region had learned
to prepare the beans of the native cacao tree. The earliest records tell us the beans
were ground and mixed with cornmeal
and chili peppers to create a drink - not a relaxing cup of hot cocoa, but a bitter, invigorating concoction
frothing with foam. And if you thought we make
a big deal about chocolate today, the Mesoamericans had us beat. They believed that cacao
was a heavenly food gifted to humans
by a feathered serpent god, known to the Maya as Kukulkan and to the Aztecs as Quetzalcoatl. Aztecs used cacao beans as currency and drank chocolate at royal feasts, gave it to soldiers as a reward
for success in battle, and used it in rituals. The first transatlantic
chocolate encounter occurred in 1519 when Hernán Cortés visited
the court of Moctezuma at Tenochtitlan. As recorded by Cortés's lieutenant, the king had 50 jugs of the drink
brought out and poured into golden cups. When the colonists returned with shipments
of the strange new bean, missionaries' salacious accounts
of native customs gave it a reputation as an aphrodisiac. At first, its bitter taste made it
suitable as a medicine for ailments, like upset stomachs, but sweetening it with honey,
sugar, or vanilla quickly made chocolate a popular delicacy
in the Spanish court. And soon, no aristocratic home was
complete without dedicated chocolate ware. The fashionable drink was difficult
and time consuming to produce on a large scale. That involved using plantations
and imported slave labor in the Caribbean and 
on islands off the coast of Africa. The world of chocolate would change
forever in 1828 with the introduction of the cocoa press
by Coenraad van Houten of Amsterdam. Van Houten's invention could separate
the cocoa's natural fat, or cocoa butter. This left a powder that could be mixed
into a drinkable solution or recombined with the cocoa butter to create the solid chocolate
we know today. Not long after, a Swiss chocolatier
named Daniel Peter added powdered milk to the mix, thus inventing milk chocolate. By the 20th century, chocolate
was no longer an elite luxury but had become a treat for the public. Meeting the massive demand required
more cultivation of cocoa, which can only grow near the equator. Now, instead of African slaves 
being shipped to South American cocoa plantations, cocoa production itself would shift
to West Africa with Cote d'Ivoire providing two-fifths
of the world's cocoa as of 2015. Yet along with the growth
of the industry, there have been horrific abuses
of human rights. Many of the plantations throughout
West Africa, which supply Western companies, use slave and child labor, with an estimation of more than
2 million children affected. This is a complex problem
that persists despite efforts from major chocolate
companies to partner with African nations to reduce child 
and indentured labor practices. Today, chocolate has established itself
in the rituals of our modern culture. Due to its colonial association with
native cultures, combined with the power of advertising, chocolate retains an aura
of something sensual, decadent, and forbidden. Yet knowing more about its fascinating
and often cruel history, as well as its production today, tells us where 
these associations originate and what they hide. So as you unwrap 
your next bar of chocolate, take a moment to consider that
not everything about chocolate is sweet.
