Its usage has decreased to the point where some argue it's being underutilized, with judges granting less than 30% of employers' requests to dismiss employment discrimination cases. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What are some advantages of juries, and why did the founders of the United States trust in their wisdom? Options: A. Juries are costly, time-consuming, and may make errors, but they have their advantages. When properly selected, jurors are more representative of the general population and don't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders trusted in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches of government., B. Juries are efficient, cost-effective, and always make correct decisions, but they have their disadvantages. When improperly selected, jurors are less representative of the general population and have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders distrusted the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches of government., C. Juries are costly, time-consuming, and may make errors, but they have their advantages. When improperly selected, jurors are less representative of the general population and have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders distrusted the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches of government., D. Juries are efficient, cost-effective, and always make correct decisions, but they have their disadvantages. When properly selected, jurors are more representative of the general population and don't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders trusted in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches of government. Correct Option: A
Question 7: Imagine you are a policymaker tasked with reforming the jury system in the United States. What steps would you take to address the decline of jury trials and ensure that the jury system survives into the future? Options: A. I would increase the use of summary judgement and plea bargaining to reduce the number of jury trials., B. I would decrease the use of summary judgement and plea bargaining to increase the number of jury trials., C. I would implement measures to ensure that jurors are properly selected and representative of the general population, and provide incentives for people to serve on juries., D. I would abolish the jury system altogether and replace it with a system of professional arbitrators. Correct Option: C
Question 8: Analyze the impact of arbitration on the jury system. How does it affect the right to a trial by jury, and what are some potential drawbacks of arbitration? Options: A. Arbitration has no impact on the jury system, as it is a separate process that does not affect the right to a trial by jury. There are no potential drawbacks to arbitration., B. Arbitration has a positive impact on the jury system, as it provides an alternative to trial by jury and can be more efficient and cost-effective. There are no potential drawbacks to arbitration., C. Arbitration has a negative impact on the jury system, as it can bypass the right to a trial by jury and may result in biased decisions. Some potential drawbacks of arbitration include the risk of arbitrator bias and the lack of transparency in the arbitration process., D. Arbitration has a neutral impact on the jury system, as it is a separate process that does not affect the right to a trial by jury. There are some potential drawbacks to arbitration, including the risk of arbitrator bias and the lack of transparency in the arbitration process. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Evaluate the argument that the decline of the jury system is a good thing. What are some potential benefits and drawbacks of this trend, and how do they impact the administration of justice? Options: A. The decline of the jury system is a good thing, as it reduces the cost and time associated with jury trials and allows for more efficient and cost-effective resolution of disputes. There are no potential drawbacks to this trend., B. The decline of the jury system is a bad thing, as it undermines the right to a trial by jury and may result in biased decisions. There are no potential benefits to this trend., C. The decline of the jury system has both positive and negative impacts. On the one hand, it can reduce the cost and time associated with jury trials and allow for more efficient and cost-effective resolution of disputes. On the other hand, it can undermine the right to a trial by jury and may result in biased decisions., D. The decline of the jury system has no impact on the administration of justice, as it is a neutral trend that does not affect the right to a trial by jury or the resolution of disputes. Correct Option: C
Question 10: Synthesize the information presented in the transcript to argue for or against the following statement: "The jury system is an essential component of the US legal system and should be preserved." Options: A. I argue for the statement, as the jury system provides a unique opportunity for citizens to participate in the administration of justice and ensures that decisions are made by impartial groups of citizens., B. I argue against the statement, as the jury system is costly, time-consuming, and may make errors, and alternative methods of dispute resolution, such as arbitration, are more efficient and cost-effective., C. I argue that the statement is partially true, as the jury system has its advantages and disadvantages, and its preservation depends on the context and circumstances of each case., D. I argue that the statement is irrelevant, as the jury system is no longer an essential component of the US legal system and has been replaced by alternative methods of dispute resolution. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: In which country did trial by jury become a fundamental feature of the legal system, checking the government and involving citizens in decision-making? Options: A. United States, B. England, C. Greece, D. Rome Correct Option: B**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Dating back at least 
to the time of Socrates, some early societies decided
that certain disputes, such as whether a person committed
a particular crime, should be heard by a group of citizens. Several centuries later, trial by jury
was introduced to England, where it became a fundamental feature
of the legal system, checking the government 
and involving citizens in decision-making. Juries decided whether defendants
would be tried on crimes, determined whether the accused
defendants were guilty, and resolved monetary disputes. While the American colonies eventually
cast off England's rule, its legal tradition of the jury persisted. The United States Constitution 
instructed a grand jury to decide whether 
criminal cases proceeded, required a jury to try all crimes,
except impeachment, and provided for juries 
in civil cases as well. Yet, in the US today,
grand juries often are not convened, and juries decide less than 4%
of criminal cases and less than 1% of civil cases
filed in court. That's at the same time as jury systems
in other countries are growing. So what happened in the U.S.? Part of the story lies in how the Supreme
Court has interpreted the Constitution. It's permitted plea bargaining, which now occurs in almost 
every criminal case. The way it works is the prosecutor
presents the accused with a decision of whether 
to plead guilty. If they accept the plea, the case won't
go in front of a jury, but they'll receive 
a shorter prison sentence than they'd get if 
a jury did convict them. The risk of a much greater 
prison sentence after a trial can frighten even an innocent defendant
into taking a plea. Between the 19th century 
and the 21st century, the proportion of guilty pleas
has increased from around 20% to 90%, and the numbers continue to grow. The Supreme Court has permitted
the use of another procedure that interferes with the jury called summary judgement. Using summary judgement, judges can
decide that civil trials are unnecessary if the people who sue 
have insufficient evidence. This is intended only for cases
where no reasonable jury would disagree. That's a difficult thing 
to determine, yet usage of summary judgement
has stretched to the point where some would argue it's being abused. For instance, judges grant fully,
or in part, over 70% of employers' requests to dismiss employment 
discrimination cases. In other cases, both the person who sues
and the person who defends forgo their right to go to court, instead resolving their dispute through
a professional arbitrator. These are generally lawyers, professors,
or former judges. Arbitration can be a smart decision
by both parties to avoid the requirements 
of a trial in court, but it's often agreed to unwittingly
when people sign contracts like employment applications
and consumer agreements. That can become a problem. For example, some arbitrators 
may be biased towards the companies
that give them cases. These are just some of the ways
in which juries have disappeared. But could the disappearance of juries
be a good thing? Well, juries aren't perfect. They're costly, time-consuming, and may make errors. And they're not always necessary, like when people can simply agree
to settle their disputes. But juries have their advantages. When properly selected, jurors are more representative of
the general population and don't have the same incentives
as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders of the United States trusted
in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches
of government. And the jury trial itself has given
ordinary citizens a central role in upholding
the social fabric. So will the jury system in the U.S.
survive into the future?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A judge can prevent a case from going to a jury in a civil case by ordering __________.
Options: A. Summary judgment, B. Arbitration, C. Jail, D. Settlement
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which country did trial by jury become a fundamental feature of the legal system, checking the government and involving citizens in decision-making? Options: A. United States, B. England, C. Greece, D. Rome Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary function of a grand jury in the United States, according to the Constitution? Options: A. To try all crimes, except impeachment, B. To decide whether criminal cases proceed, C. To provide for juries in civil cases, D. To resolve monetary disputes Correct Option: B
Question 3: What has contributed to the decline of jury trials in the United States, with juries now deciding less than 4% of criminal cases and less than 1% of civil cases? Options: A. The increasing use of summary judgement and plea bargaining, B. The growing number of jury trials in other countries, C. The decreasing number of crimes committed in the US, D. The increasing number of civil cases filed in court Correct Option: A
Question 4: How does plea bargaining work in the US, and what is its effect on the jury system? Options: A. The prosecutor presents the accused with a decision to plead guilty, and if accepted, the case won't go to trial, resulting in a shorter prison sentence. This has led to an increase in guilty pleas and a decline in jury trials., B. The prosecutor presents the accused with a decision to plead not guilty, and if accepted, the case will go to trial, resulting in a longer prison sentence. This has led to a decrease in guilty pleas and an increase in jury trials., C. The prosecutor presents the accused with a decision to plead guilty, and if accepted, the case will go to trial, resulting in a longer prison sentence. This has led to a decrease in guilty pleas and an increase in jury trials., D. The prosecutor presents the accused with a decision to plead not guilty, and if accepted, the case won't go to trial, resulting in a shorter prison sentence. This has led to an increase in guilty pleas and a decline in jury trials. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is summary judgement, and how has its usage affected the jury system? Options: A. Summary judgement is a procedure where judges can decide that civil trials are unnecessary if the people who sue have insufficient evidence. Its usage has stretched to the point where some argue it's being abused, with judges granting over 70% of employers' requests to dismiss employment discrimination cases., B. Summary judgement is a procedure where judges can decide that civil trials are necessary if the people who sue have sufficient evidence. Its usage has decreased to the point where some argue it's being underutilized, with judges granting less than 30% of employers' requests to dismiss employment discrimination cases., C. Summary judgement is a procedure where judges can decide that criminal trials are unnecessary if the people who sue have insufficient evidence. Its usage has stretched to the point where some argue it's being abused, with judges granting over 70% of employers' requests to dismiss employment discrimination cases., D. Summary judgement is a procedure where judges can decide that criminal trials are necessary if the people who sue have sufficient evidence. Its usage has decreased to the point where some argue it's being underutilized, with judges granting less than 30% of employers' requests to dismiss employment discrimination cases. Correct Option: A

When properly selected, jurors are more representative of the general population and don't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders trusted in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches of government. Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[PBSDS BUMPER] The average person gets rid of approximately 130 grams of poop every day. Maybe twice that much if they’ve had Taco
Bell. Seven and a half billion of us on Earth? That’s a literal mountain of human poop
every day. Yet most of *us* get to pretend it doesn’t
exist, all thanks to an invention that has improved health and quality of life more than
any other in humanity’s history. [OPEN BUMPER] Bears do it in the woods, whales do it in the ocean, and 2.4 *billion* of us DON’T
do it in a toilet. Dysentery, typhoid, parasites, and other infections
lead to hundreds of thousands of deaths every year, all because one in three people alive
in 2017 don’t have access to toilets and latrines. From on top of our porcelain thrones, we’ve
left a lot of our species drowning in feces. Nearly a *billion* people still defecate out
in the open: in street gutters, open water, or… in the woods. Thousands of years ago, we all did it that
way, but as we developed agriculture and settled into towns, poop started piling up. Around five thousand years ago, Neolithic
villagers constructed the first known toilets at Skara Brae. At the same time, many houses in Mohenjo Daro,
featured toilets complete with drains, people washed their poop into sewers that emptied
into the Indus River. It’d be thousands of years before we linked
germs to disease, but avoiding filth has deep evolutionary roots. Bodily excretions, death, and rotten smells
can be signs of danger or disease, triggering our innate sense of disgust. This biological instinct ended up in the moral
codes of many religions, like this passage from the Old Testament instructing the Hebrews
to do their Exodus in a… hole-y fashion. Roman society was comfortable with caca. At one point, Rome had 144 public toilets…
long open benches that emptied into the Cloaca Maxima, a sewer system that carried waste
to the Tiber river. But the vast majority of Romans simply pooped
in a pot and threw it into the street. As waste and disease piled up, Romans pointed
to the stink as the cause of sickness. After the Roman Empire faded away, this connection
between bad air and bad health persisted, clogging up toilet innovation for more than
a thousand years. During medieval outbreaks like the Plague,
doctors wore pointed masks, filled with strong herbs or perfumes to “cleanse” bad air,
which they believed to be the cause of disease. They were wrong, but this obsession with stink
would change the world in ways no one saw coming. Contrary to popular belief, Thomas Crapper
didn’t invent the flush toilet. That honor goes to John Harington, his “Ajax”
device emptied the bowl with water from an overhead tank. But flush toilets didn’t catch on until
1775, when Alexander Cummings revolutionized the way we poo by adding a water-filled “S
trap” to block explosive, and supposedly disease-causing sewer gas from rising up the
pipes, the same basic toilet design we still use today. During the Industrial Revolution, most people’s
business still ended up in streets and cesspools, and the growing population was too big a load
for London’s sewers. By the mid-1800s, the city was literally overflowing
with crap. With crap comes cholera, an infection from
bacteria whose toxins basically cause all the water in your body to pour out of your
butt in the form of diarrhea, death by dehydration. Cholera hit London in 1854. Instead of the “old bad air” theory, a
doctor named John Snow believed cholera was transmitted by drinking water tainted with
sewage. Snow’s map of cholera cases clustered around
a water pump. When he when he removed the pump’s handle,
new cholera cases fell. Soon after, London enclosed its sewers and
diverted waste downstream of London, but doctors wouldn’t totally accept Snow’s ideas for
nearly 50 years. The Great Depression saw an expansion of sewage
treatment plants–and modern toilet paper!–and this is basically the sanitation system we
have today, where magical chairs make nasty things disappear, out of sight, out of smell,
and out of mind. It’s no three sea shells but we've come a long way. …and this privileged pooping existence lets
us keep something else out of mind: The 2.4 BILLION people who still don’t have toilets. Nearly 800,000 children under 5 still die
every year from diarrhea. More than AIDS, more than malaria. That’s an Airbus A380 full of children crashing
every 6 hours. It’s estimated last year poor sanitation
cost the global economy $260 billion, due to illness, loss of income, and years of life
lost. Worse, women suffer these impacts disproportionately
to men. In 2007, readers of the BMJ voted “modern
sanitation” as the #1 medical advance since 1840. Not antibiotics, not vaccines. Toilets and clean water. We *have* made progress. Since 1990, 14% more people have access to
sanitation, and *many* fewer are dying, but fewer is not zero. With a little effort, we can *wipe* this problem
from the Earth. On the TV show “The Brady Bunch”, their
bathroom didn’t even have a toilet. Pooping is so taboo, it was *literally* invisible. We can’t even talk about it! It’s no coincidence that many of our worst
swear words involve defecation. In her book The Big Necessity, Rose George
writes: “How a society disposes of its human excrement is an indication of how it treats
its humans too” Everybody poops, and every person who is born
should be able to do it safely. Stay curious! And please… always wash your hands when you’re done. Hey everyone, as always, thank you for watching
and learning with us. This week’s video was a stinky but important
subject, and it was brought to you thanks to the support of Bill and Melinda Gates. For years, Bill and Melinda Gates have supported
efforts around the world to make people healthier and make their lives better through innovation,
education, and investing in projects to build a better future. And it’s working! Since 1990, an estimated **122 million** children’s
lives have been saved, thanks to things like better nutrition, family planning, economic
opportunities, and vaccines. Here’s some proof: In 1988 there were more
than 350,000 cases of polio. And last year? Only 34. Things have gotten a LOT better, and one day
soon, that number *can be, and will be zero*. But whether it’s bringing toilets to 2.4
billion people, or erasing the last few cases of polio, progress only happens when the privileged
pay attention. Go to gatesletter.com to read Bill and Melinda
Gates’ Annual Letter, and find out all the ways life has and will continue to improve
for the world’s poorest I’ll see you next time.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question:  How much feces does the average person excrete per day?
Options: A. 130 pounds, B. 13 grams, C. 130 grams, D. there is no answer to this question
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated amount of poop produced by an average person per day? Options: A. 100 grams, B. 130 grams, C. 200 grams, D. 250 grams Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the leading cause of death among children under 5? Options: A. AIDS, B. Malaria, C. Diarrhea, D. Malnutrition Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the major innovation introduced by Alexander Cummings in 1775 that revolutionized the flush toilet? Options: A. The S-trap design, B. The overhead tank system, C. The use of porcelain in toilets, D. The concept of sewage treatment plants Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name of the doctor who discovered the link between cholera and contaminated water in London in 1854? Options: A. John Snow, B. Thomas Crapper, C. Alexander Cummings, D. John Harington Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the estimated economic cost of poor sanitation worldwide? Options: A. $100 billion, B. $260 billion, C. $500 billion, D. $1 trillion Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the significance of the "S-trap" design in modern toilets? Options: A. It prevents sewer gas from rising up the pipes, B. It increases the water pressure in the toilet, C. It reduces the amount of water used per flush, D. It improves the aesthetic design of toilets Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name of the book written by Rose George that explores the issue of sanitation and human excrement? Options: A. The Big Necessity, B. The Porcelain Throne, C. The Sanitation Solution, D. The Toilet Revolution Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the estimated number of children's lives saved since 1990 due to efforts to improve global health? Options: A. 10 million, B. 50 million, C. 122 million, D. 200 million Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the name of the ancient city that featured toilets with drains and a sewage system around 5,000 years ago? Options: A. Skara Brae, B. Mohenjo Daro, C. Rome, D. London Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why progress in sanitation and global health is often hindered? Options: A. Lack of funding, B. Limited access to technology, C. Insufficient awareness and attention from privileged communities, D. Corruption and mismanagement Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: What is the estimated amount of poop produced by an average person per day? Options: A. 100 grams, B. 130 grams, C. 200 grams, D. 250 grams Correct Option: B**

This question has the same intent and content as the ground truth MCQ, with similar options and a correct answer that matches the ground truth.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **1**

and out of mind. It’s no three sea shells but we've come a long way. …and this privileged pooping existence lets
us keep something else out of mind: The 2.4 BILLION people who still don’t have toilets. Nearly 800,000 children under 5 still die
every year from diarrhea. More than AIDS, more than malaria. That’s an Airbus A380 full of children crashing
every 6 hours. It’s estimated last year poor sanitation
cost the global economy $260 billion, due to illness, loss of income, and years of life
lost. Worse, women suffer these impacts disproportionately
to men. In 2007, readers of the BMJ voted “modern
sanitation” as the #1 medical advance since 1840. Not antibiotics, not vaccines. Toilets and clean water. We *have* made progress. Since 1990, 14% more people have access to
sanitation, and *many* fewer are dying, but fewer is not zero. With a little effort, we can *wipe* this problem
from the Earth. On the TV show “The Brady Bunch”, their
bathroom didn’t even have a toilet. Pooping is so taboo, it was *literally* invisible. We can’t even talk about it! It’s no coincidence that many of our worst
swear words involve defecation. In her book The Big Necessity, Rose George
writes: “How a society disposes of its human excrement is an indication of how it treats
its humans too” Everybody poops, and every person who is born
should be able to do it safely. Stay curious! And please… always wash your hands when you’re done. Hey everyone, as always, thank you for watching
and learning with us. This week’s video was a stinky but important
subject, and it was brought to you thanks to the support of Bill and Melinda Gates. For years, Bill and Melinda Gates have supported
efforts around the world to make people healthier and make their lives better through innovation,
education, and investing in projects to build a better future. And it’s working! Since 1990, an estimated **122 million** children’s
lives have been saved, thanks to things like better nutrition, family planning, economic
opportunities, and vaccines. Here’s some proof: In 1988 there were more
than 350,000 cases of polio. And last year? Only 34. Things have gotten a LOT better, and one day
soon, that number *can be, and will be zero*. But whether it’s bringing toilets to 2.4
billion people, or erasing the last few cases of polio, progress only happens when the privileged
pay attention. Go to gatesletter.com to read Bill and Melinda
Gates’ Annual Letter, and find out all the ways life has and will continue to improve
for the world’s poorest I’ll see you next time.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question:  What approximate percentage of people in the world do not have access to a toilet?
Options: A. 1%, B. approximately 32%, C. nearly 50 percent, D. only about 10%
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated amount of poop produced by an average person per day? Options: A. 100 grams, B. 130 grams, C. 200 grams, D. 250 grams Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the leading cause of death among children under 5? Options: A. AIDS, B. Malaria, C. Diarrhea, D. Malnutrition Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the major innovation introduced by Alexander Cummings in 1775 that revolutionized the flush toilet? Options: A. The S-trap design, B. The overhead tank system, C. The use of porcelain in toilets, D. The concept of sewage treatment plants Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name of the doctor who discovered the link between cholera and contaminated water in London in 1854? Options: A. John Snow, B. Thomas Crapper, C. Alexander Cummings, D. John Harington Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the estimated economic cost of poor sanitation worldwide? Options: A. $100 billion, B. $260 billion, C. $500 billion, D. $1 trillion Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the significance of the "S-trap" design in modern toilets? Options: A. It prevents sewer gas from rising up the pipes, B. It increases the water pressure in the toilet, C. It reduces the amount of water used per flush, D. It improves the aesthetic design of toilets Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name of the book written by Rose George that explores the issue of sanitation and human excrement? Options: A. The Big Necessity, B. The Porcelain Throne, C. The Sanitation Solution, D. The Toilet Revolution Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the estimated number of children's lives saved since 1990 due to efforts to improve global health? Options: A. 10 million, B. 50 million, C. 122 million, D. 200 million Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the name of the ancient city that featured toilets with drains and a sewage system around 5,000 years ago? Options: A. Skara Brae, B. Mohenjo Daro, C. Rome, D. London Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why progress in sanitation and global health is often hindered? Options: A. Lack of funding, B. Limited access to technology, C. Insufficient awareness and attention from privileged communities, D. Corruption and mismanagement Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The most similar generated MCQ is Question 2, but it does not match the ground truth MCQ. However, I noticed that the transcript mentions the statistic "2.4 billion people who still don’t have toilets" and "nearly 800,000 children under 5 still die every year from diarrhea."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[PBSDS BUMPER] The average person gets rid of approximately 130 grams of poop every day. Maybe twice that much if they’ve had Taco
Bell. Seven and a half billion of us on Earth? That’s a literal mountain of human poop
every day. Yet most of *us* get to pretend it doesn’t
exist, all thanks to an invention that has improved health and quality of life more than
any other in humanity’s history. [OPEN BUMPER] Bears do it in the woods, whales do it in the ocean, and 2.4 *billion* of us DON’T
do it in a toilet. Dysentery, typhoid, parasites, and other infections
lead to hundreds of thousands of deaths every year, all because one in three people alive
in 2017 don’t have access to toilets and latrines. From on top of our porcelain thrones, we’ve
left a lot of our species drowning in feces. Nearly a *billion* people still defecate out
in the open: in street gutters, open water, or… in the woods. Thousands of years ago, we all did it that
way, but as we developed agriculture and settled into towns, poop started piling up. Around five thousand years ago, Neolithic
villagers constructed the first known toilets at Skara Brae. At the same time, many houses in Mohenjo Daro,
featured toilets complete with drains, people washed their poop into sewers that emptied
into the Indus River. It’d be thousands of years before we linked
germs to disease, but avoiding filth has deep evolutionary roots. Bodily excretions, death, and rotten smells
can be signs of danger or disease, triggering our innate sense of disgust. This biological instinct ended up in the moral
codes of many religions, like this passage from the Old Testament instructing the Hebrews
to do their Exodus in a… hole-y fashion. Roman society was comfortable with caca. At one point, Rome had 144 public toilets…
long open benches that emptied into the Cloaca Maxima, a sewer system that carried waste
to the Tiber river. But the vast majority of Romans simply pooped
in a pot and threw it into the street. As waste and disease piled up, Romans pointed
to the stink as the cause of sickness. After the Roman Empire faded away, this connection
between bad air and bad health persisted, clogging up toilet innovation for more than
a thousand years. During medieval outbreaks like the Plague,
doctors wore pointed masks, filled with strong herbs or perfumes to “cleanse” bad air,
which they believed to be the cause of disease. They were wrong, but this obsession with stink
would change the world in ways no one saw coming. Contrary to popular belief, Thomas Crapper
didn’t invent the flush toilet. That honor goes to John Harington, his “Ajax”
device emptied the bowl with water from an overhead tank. But flush toilets didn’t catch on until
1775, when Alexander Cummings revolutionized the way we poo by adding a water-filled “S
trap” to block explosive, and supposedly disease-causing sewer gas from rising up the
pipes, the same basic toilet design we still use today. During the Industrial Revolution, most people’s
business still ended up in streets and cesspools, and the growing population was too big a load
for London’s sewers. By the mid-1800s, the city was literally overflowing
with crap. With crap comes cholera, an infection from
bacteria whose toxins basically cause all the water in your body to pour out of your
butt in the form of diarrhea, death by dehydration. Cholera hit London in 1854. Instead of the “old bad air” theory, a
doctor named John Snow believed cholera was transmitted by drinking water tainted with
sewage. Snow’s map of cholera cases clustered around
a water pump. When he when he removed the pump’s handle,
new cholera cases fell. Soon after, London enclosed its sewers and
diverted waste downstream of London, but doctors wouldn’t totally accept Snow’s ideas for
nearly 50 years. The Great Depression saw an expansion of sewage
treatment plants–and modern toilet paper!–and this is basically the sanitation system we
have today, where magical chairs make nasty things disappear, out of sight, out of smell,
and out of mind. It’s no three sea shells but we've come a long way. …and this privileged pooping existence lets
us keep something else out of mind: The 2.4 BILLION people who still don’t have toilets. Nearly 800,000 children under 5 still die
every year from diarrhea. More than AIDS, more than malaria. That’s an Airbus A380 full of children crashing
every 6 hours. It’s estimated last year poor sanitation
cost the global economy $260 billion, due to illness, loss of income, and years of life
lost. Worse, women suffer these impacts disproportionately
to men. In 2007, readers of the BMJ voted “modern
sanitation” as the #1 medical advance since 1840. Not antibiotics, not vaccines. Toilets and clean water. We *have* made progress. Since 1990, 14% more people have access to
sanitation, and *many* fewer are dying, but fewer is not zero. With a little effort, we can *wipe* this problem
from the Earth. On the TV show “The Brady Bunch”, their
bathroom didn’t even have a toilet. Pooping is so taboo, it was *literally* invisible. We can’t even talk about it! It’s no coincidence that many of our worst
swear words involve defecation. In her book The Big Necessity, Rose George
writes: “How a society disposes of its human excrement is an indication of how it treats
its humans too” Everybody poops, and every person who is born
should be able to do it safely. Stay curious! And please… always wash your hands when you’re done. Hey everyone, as always, thank you for watching
and learning with us. This week’s video was a stinky but important
subject, and it was brought to you thanks to the support of Bill and Melinda Gates. For years, Bill and Melinda Gates have supported
efforts around the world to make people healthier and make their lives better through innovation,
education, and investing in projects to build a better future. And it’s working! Since 1990, an estimated **122 million** children’s
lives have been saved, thanks to things like better nutrition, family planning, economic
opportunities, and vaccines. Here’s some proof: In 1988 there were more
than 350,000 cases of polio. And last year? Only 34. Things have gotten a LOT better, and one day
soon, that number *can be, and will be zero*. But whether it’s bringing toilets to 2.4
billion people, or erasing the last few cases of polio, progress only happens when the privileged
pay attention. Go to gatesletter.com to read Bill and Melinda
Gates’ Annual Letter, and find out all the ways life has and will continue to improve
for the world’s poorest I’ll see you next time.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What change in lifestyle caused "poop to start piling up?"
Options: A. the change to an agricultural society, B. moving into towns, C. it was just a more convenient way to collect it, D. a and b only, E. all of the above
Correct Option: D

doctor named John Snow believed cholera was transmitted by drinking water tainted with
sewage. Snow’s map of cholera cases clustered around
a water pump. When he when he removed the pump’s handle,
new cholera cases fell. Soon after, London enclosed its sewers and
diverted waste downstream of London, but doctors wouldn’t totally accept Snow’s ideas for
nearly 50 years. The Great Depression saw an expansion of sewage
treatment plants–and modern toilet paper!–and this is basically the sanitation system we
have today, where magical chairs make nasty things disappear, out of sight, out of smell,
and out of mind. It’s no three sea shells but we've come a long way. …and this privileged pooping existence lets
us keep something else out of mind: The 2.4 BILLION people who still don’t have toilets. Nearly 800,000 children under 5 still die
every year from diarrhea. More than AIDS, more than malaria. That’s an Airbus A380 full of children crashing
every 6 hours. It’s estimated last year poor sanitation
cost the global economy $260 billion, due to illness, loss of income, and years of life
lost. Worse, women suffer these impacts disproportionately
to men. In 2007, readers of the BMJ voted “modern
sanitation” as the #1 medical advance since 1840. Not antibiotics, not vaccines. Toilets and clean water. We *have* made progress. Since 1990, 14% more people have access to
sanitation, and *many* fewer are dying, but fewer is not zero. With a little effort, we can *wipe* this problem
from the Earth. On the TV show “The Brady Bunch”, their
bathroom didn’t even have a toilet. Pooping is so taboo, it was *literally* invisible. We can’t even talk about it! It’s no coincidence that many of our worst
swear words involve defecation. In her book The Big Necessity, Rose George
writes: “How a society disposes of its human excrement is an indication of how it treats
its humans too” Everybody poops, and every person who is born
should be able to do it safely. Stay curious! And please… always wash your hands when you’re done. Hey everyone, as always, thank you for watching
and learning with us. This week’s video was a stinky but important
subject, and it was brought to you thanks to the support of Bill and Melinda Gates. For years, Bill and Melinda Gates have supported
efforts around the world to make people healthier and make their lives better through innovation,
education, and investing in projects to build a better future. And it’s working! Since 1990, an estimated **122 million** children’s
lives have been saved, thanks to things like better nutrition, family planning, economic
opportunities, and vaccines. Here’s some proof: In 1988 there were more
than 350,000 cases of polio. And last year? Only 34. Things have gotten a LOT better, and one day
soon, that number *can be, and will be zero*. But whether it’s bringing toilets to 2.4
billion people, or erasing the last few cases of polio, progress only happens when the privileged
pay attention. Go to gatesletter.com to read Bill and Melinda
Gates’ Annual Letter, and find out all the ways life has and will continue to improve
for the world’s poorest I’ll see you next time.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The most common cause of death due to cholera is from
Options: A. excessive loss of blood, B. blood poisoning, C. vomiting, D. diarrhea and dehydration
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated amount of poop produced by an average person per day? Options: A. 100 grams, B. 130 grams, C. 200 grams, D. 250 grams Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the leading cause of death among children under 5? Options: A. AIDS, B. Malaria, C. Diarrhea, D. Malnutrition Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the major innovation introduced by Alexander Cummings in 1775 that revolutionized the flush toilet? Options: A. The S-trap design, B. The overhead tank system, C. The use of porcelain in toilets, D. The concept of sewage treatment plants Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name of the doctor who discovered the link between cholera and contaminated water in London in 1854? Options: A. John Snow, B. Thomas Crapper, C. Alexander Cummings, D. John Harington Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the estimated economic cost of poor sanitation worldwide? Options: A. $100 billion, B. $260 billion, C. $500 billion, D. $1 trillion Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the significance of the "S-trap" design in modern toilets? Options: A. It prevents sewer gas from rising up the pipes, B. It increases the water pressure in the toilet, C. It reduces the amount of water used per flush, D. It improves the aesthetic design of toilets Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name of the book written by Rose George that explores the issue of sanitation and human excrement? Options: A. The Big Necessity, B. The Porcelain Throne, C. The Sanitation Solution, D. The Toilet Revolution Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the estimated number of children's lives saved since 1990 due to efforts to improve global health? Options: A. 10 million, B. 50 million, C. 122 million, D. 200 million Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the name of the ancient city that featured toilets with drains and a sewage system around 5,000 years ago? Options: A. Skara Brae, B. Mohenjo Daro, C. Rome, D. London Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why progress in sanitation and global health is often hindered? Options: A. Lack of funding, B. Limited access to technology, C. Insufficient awareness and attention from privileged communities, D. Corruption and mismanagement Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Approximately 7 million people around the 
world die from heart attacks every year, and cardiovascular disease, which causes heart attacks and other
problems like strokes, is the world's leading killer. So what causes a heart attack? Like all muscles, the heart needs oxygen, and during a heart attack,
it can't get enough. Fatty deposits, or plaques, develop on the walls 
of our coronary arteries. Those are the vessels that supply
oxygenated blood to the heart. These plaques grow as we age, sometimes getting chunky, hardened, or enflamed. Eventually, the plaques can turn
into blockages. If one of the plaques ruptures or cracks, a blood clot will form around it
in minutes, and a partially closed artery
can become completely blocked. Blood flow is cut off 
to the cardiac muscle and the oxygen-starved cells start to die
within several minutes. This is a myocardial infarction, or heart attack. Things can rapidly deteriorate
in the absence of treatment. The injured muscle may not be able
to pump blood as well, and its rhythm might be thrown off. In the worst case scenario,
a heart attack can cause sudden death. And how do you know that someone
is having a heart attack? The most common symptom is chest pain caused by the oxygen-deprived 
heart muscle. Patients describe it as crushing
or vice-like. It can radiate to the left arm, jaw, back, or abdomen. But it's not always as sudden and dramatic
as it is in the movies. Some people experience nausea or shortness of breath. Symptoms may be less prominent
in women and the elderly. For them, weakness and tiredness
may be the main signal. And surprisingly, in many people, especially those with diabetes,
which affects the nerves that carry pain, a heart attack may be silent. If you think that someone might be 
having a heart attack, the most important thing 
is to respond quickly. If you have access to emergency medical
services, call them. They're the fastest way 
to get to a hospital. Taking aspirin, which thins the blood, and nitroglycerin, 
which opens up the artery, can help keep the heart attack
from getting worse. In the emergency room, 
doctors can diagnose a heart attack. They commonly use an electrocardiogram to measure the heart's 
electrical activity and a blood test to assess 
heart muscle damage. The patient is then taken to a high-tech
cardiac suite where tests are done 
to locate the blockages. Cardiologists can reopen 
the blocked artery by inflating it with a balloon
in a procedure called an angioplasty. Frequently, they also insert a metal
or polymer stent that will hold the artery open. More extensive blockages might require
coronary artery bypass surgery. Using a piece of vein or artery
from another part of the body, heart surgeons can reroute blood flow
around the blockage. These procedures reestablish circulation
to the cardiac muscle, restoring heart function. Heart attack treatment is advancing, but prevention is vital. Genetics and lifestyle factors
both affect your risk. And the good news is that you can
change your lifestyle. Exercise, a healthy diet,
and weight loss all lower the risk of heart attacks, whether you've had one before or not. Doctors recommend exercising
a few times a week, doing both aerobic activity
and strength training. A heart-healthy diet is low
in sugar and saturated fats, which are both linked to heart disease. So what should you eat? Lots of fiber from vegetables, chicken and fish instead of red meat, whole grains and nuts like walnuts
and almonds all seem to be beneficial. A good diet and exercise plan can also
keep your weight in a healthy range, which will lower 
your heart attack risk as well. And of course, medications can also
help prevent heart attacks. Doctors often prescribe low-dose
aspirin, for example, particularly for patients who've
already had a heart attack and for those known to be
at high risk. And drugs that help manage risk factors, like high blood pressure, cholesterol,
and diabetes, will make heart attacks less likely, too. Heart attacks may be common, 
but they don't have to be inevitable. A healthy diet, avoiding tobacco use, staying fit, and enjoying plenty of sleep
and lots of laughter all go a long way in making sure
your body's most important muscle keeps on beating.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many deaths occur annually around the world from cardiovascular disease?
Options: A. 500,000, B. 3 million, C. 7 million, D. 100 million
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the world's leading killer, according to the transcript? Options: A. Cancer, B. Cardiovascular disease, C. Stroke, D. Diabetes Correct Option: B
Question 2: What happens to the heart during a heart attack? Options: A. It gets too much oxygen, B. It can't get enough oxygen, C. It becomes inflamed, D. It stops beating Correct Option: B
Question 3: A 55-year-old man is experiencing chest pain that radiates to his left arm. What should he do? Options: A. Take some rest and hope it goes away, B. Call emergency medical services, C. Take some painkillers, D. Go to the hospital the next day Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the purpose of an electrocardiogram in diagnosing a heart attack? Options: A. To measure blood pressure, B. To assess heart muscle damage, C. To measure the heart's electrical activity, D. To locate blockages Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the name of the procedure where a balloon is used to reopen a blocked artery? Options: A. Angioplasty, B. Coronary artery bypass surgery, C. Heart transplant, D. Stent insertion Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the relationship between fatty deposits and heart attacks? Options: A. Fatty deposits help prevent heart attacks, B. Fatty deposits have no relation to heart attacks, C. Fatty deposits can develop into blockages, leading to heart attacks, D. Fatty deposits only occur in people with diabetes Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can a healthy diet help prevent heart attacks? Options: A. By increasing sugar and saturated fat intake, B. By lowering sugar and saturated fat intake, C. By eating more red meat, D. By avoiding vegetables and whole grains Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the benefit of exercising a few times a week, according to the transcript? Options: A. It increases the risk of heart attacks, B. It has no effect on heart attack risk, C. It lowers the risk of heart attacks, D. It only benefits people who have already had a heart attack Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the purpose of prescribing low-dose aspirin to patients who have already had a heart attack? Options: A. To thin the blood and prevent further heart attacks, B. To increase blood pressure, C. To lower cholesterol levels, D. To manage diabetes Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the overall message of the transcript regarding heart attacks? Options: A. Heart attacks are inevitable and cannot be prevented, B. Heart attacks are common, but can be prevented with a healthy lifestyle and medical treatment, C. Heart attacks only occur in people with diabetes, D. Heart attacks are not a significant health concern Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. However, the options provided in Question 1 do not match the intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the number of deaths that occur annually due to cardiovascular disease.

A closer examination of the generated MCQs reveals that none of them directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, if I had to choose the most similar one, I would say that Question 1 is the closest, but with a caveat that it does not accurately match the ground truth MCQ.

If I were to create a new MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ, it would be:

Question: How many deaths occur annually around the world from heart attacks?
Options: A. 500,000, B. 3 million, C. 7 million, D. 100 million

This new MCQ directly matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

However, since I need to provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ, I would say that the index is 1, with the understanding that it does not accurately match the ground truth MCQ.

Index: 1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Approximately 7 million people around the 
world die from heart attacks every year, and cardiovascular disease, which causes heart attacks and other
problems like strokes, is the world's leading killer. So what causes a heart attack? Like all muscles, the heart needs oxygen, and during a heart attack,
it can't get enough. Fatty deposits, or plaques, develop on the walls 
of our coronary arteries. Those are the vessels that supply
oxygenated blood to the heart. These plaques grow as we age, sometimes getting chunky, hardened, or enflamed. Eventually, the plaques can turn
into blockages. If one of the plaques ruptures or cracks, a blood clot will form around it
in minutes, and a partially closed artery
can become completely blocked. Blood flow is cut off 
to the cardiac muscle and the oxygen-starved cells start to die
within several minutes. This is a myocardial infarction, or heart attack. Things can rapidly deteriorate
in the absence of treatment. The injured muscle may not be able
to pump blood as well, and its rhythm might be thrown off. In the worst case scenario,
a heart attack can cause sudden death. And how do you know that someone
is having a heart attack? The most common symptom is chest pain caused by the oxygen-deprived 
heart muscle. Patients describe it as crushing
or vice-like. It can radiate to the left arm, jaw, back, or abdomen. But it's not always as sudden and dramatic
as it is in the movies. Some people experience nausea or shortness of breath. Symptoms may be less prominent
in women and the elderly. For them, weakness and tiredness
may be the main signal. And surprisingly, in many people, especially those with diabetes,
which affects the nerves that carry pain, a heart attack may be silent. If you think that someone might be 
having a heart attack, the most important thing 
is to respond quickly. If you have access to emergency medical
services, call them. They're the fastest way 
to get to a hospital. Taking aspirin, which thins the blood, and nitroglycerin, 
which opens up the artery, can help keep the heart attack
from getting worse. In the emergency room, 
doctors can diagnose a heart attack. They commonly use an electrocardiogram to measure the heart's 
electrical activity and a blood test to assess 
heart muscle damage. The patient is then taken to a high-tech
cardiac suite where tests are done 
to locate the blockages. Cardiologists can reopen 
the blocked artery by inflating it with a balloon
in a procedure called an angioplasty. Frequently, they also insert a metal
or polymer stent that will hold the artery open. More extensive blockages might require
coronary artery bypass surgery. Using a piece of vein or artery
from another part of the body, heart surgeons can reroute blood flow
around the blockage. These procedures reestablish circulation
to the cardiac muscle, restoring heart function. Heart attack treatment is advancing, but prevention is vital. Genetics and lifestyle factors
both affect your risk. And the good news is that you can
change your lifestyle. Exercise, a healthy diet,
and weight loss all lower the risk of heart attacks, whether you've had one before or not. Doctors recommend exercising
a few times a week, doing both aerobic activity
and strength training. A heart-healthy diet is low
in sugar and saturated fats, which are both linked to heart disease. So what should you eat? Lots of fiber from vegetables, chicken and fish instead of red meat, whole grains and nuts like walnuts
and almonds all seem to be beneficial. A good diet and exercise plan can also
keep your weight in a healthy range, which will lower 
your heart attack risk as well. And of course, medications can also
help prevent heart attacks. Doctors often prescribe low-dose
aspirin, for example, particularly for patients who've
already had a heart attack and for those known to be
at high risk. And drugs that help manage risk factors, like high blood pressure, cholesterol,
and diabetes, will make heart attacks less likely, too. Heart attacks may be common, 
but they don't have to be inevitable. A healthy diet, avoiding tobacco use, staying fit, and enjoying plenty of sleep
and lots of laughter all go a long way in making sure
your body's most important muscle keeps on beating.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the hospital, which of the following treatments might be used for a patient with a blocked artery?
Options: A. Balloon angioplasty, B. Stenting, C. Bypass surgery, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Question 2: What happens to the heart during a heart attack? Options: A. It gets too much oxygen, B. It can't get enough oxygen, C. It becomes inflamed, D. It stops beating Correct Option: B
Question 3: A 55-year-old man is experiencing chest pain that radiates to his left arm. What should he do? Options: A. Take some rest and hope it goes away, B. Call emergency medical services, C. Take some painkillers, D. Go to the hospital the next day Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the purpose of an electrocardiogram in diagnosing a heart attack? Options: A. To measure blood pressure, B. To assess heart muscle damage, C. To measure the heart's electrical activity, D. To locate blockages Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the name of the procedure where a balloon is used to reopen a blocked artery? Options: A. Angioplasty, B. Coronary artery bypass surgery, C. Heart transplant, D. Stent insertion Correct Option: A

It lowers the risk of heart attacks, D. It only benefits people who have already had a heart attack Correct Option: C

Question 10: What is the overall message of the transcript regarding heart attacks? Options: A. Heart attacks are inevitable and cannot be prevented, B. Heart attacks are common, but can be prevented with a healthy lifestyle and medical treatment, C. Heart attacks only occur in people with diabetes, D. Heart attacks are not a significant health concern Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Approximately 7 million people around the 
world die from heart attacks every year, and cardiovascular disease, which causes heart attacks and other
problems like strokes, is the world's leading killer. So what causes a heart attack? Like all muscles, the heart needs oxygen, and during a heart attack,
it can't get enough. Fatty deposits, or plaques, develop on the walls 
of our coronary arteries. Those are the vessels that supply
oxygenated blood to the heart. These plaques grow as we age, sometimes getting chunky, hardened, or enflamed. Eventually, the plaques can turn
into blockages. If one of the plaques ruptures or cracks, a blood clot will form around it
in minutes, and a partially closed artery
can become completely blocked. Blood flow is cut off 
to the cardiac muscle and the oxygen-starved cells start to die
within several minutes. This is a myocardial infarction, or heart attack. Things can rapidly deteriorate
in the absence of treatment. The injured muscle may not be able
to pump blood as well, and its rhythm might be thrown off. In the worst case scenario,
a heart attack can cause sudden death. And how do you know that someone
is having a heart attack? The most common symptom is chest pain caused by the oxygen-deprived 
heart muscle. Patients describe it as crushing
or vice-like. It can radiate to the left arm, jaw, back, or abdomen. But it's not always as sudden and dramatic
as it is in the movies. Some people experience nausea or shortness of breath. Symptoms may be less prominent
in women and the elderly. For them, weakness and tiredness
may be the main signal. And surprisingly, in many people, especially those with diabetes,
which affects the nerves that carry pain, a heart attack may be silent. If you think that someone might be 
having a heart attack, the most important thing 
is to respond quickly. If you have access to emergency medical
services, call them. They're the fastest way 
to get to a hospital. Taking aspirin, which thins the blood, and nitroglycerin, 
which opens up the artery, can help keep the heart attack
from getting worse. In the emergency room, 
doctors can diagnose a heart attack. They commonly use an electrocardiogram to measure the heart's 
electrical activity and a blood test to assess 
heart muscle damage. The patient is then taken to a high-tech
cardiac suite where tests are done 
to locate the blockages. Cardiologists can reopen 
the blocked artery by inflating it with a balloon
in a procedure called an angioplasty. Frequently, they also insert a metal
or polymer stent that will hold the artery open. More extensive blockages might require
coronary artery bypass surgery. Using a piece of vein or artery
from another part of the body, heart surgeons can reroute blood flow
around the blockage. These procedures reestablish circulation
to the cardiac muscle, restoring heart function. Heart attack treatment is advancing, but prevention is vital. Genetics and lifestyle factors
both affect your risk. And the good news is that you can
change your lifestyle. Exercise, a healthy diet,
and weight loss all lower the risk of heart attacks, whether you've had one before or not. Doctors recommend exercising
a few times a week, doing both aerobic activity
and strength training. A heart-healthy diet is low
in sugar and saturated fats, which are both linked to heart disease. So what should you eat? Lots of fiber from vegetables, chicken and fish instead of red meat, whole grains and nuts like walnuts
and almonds all seem to be beneficial. A good diet and exercise plan can also
keep your weight in a healthy range, which will lower 
your heart attack risk as well. And of course, medications can also
help prevent heart attacks. Doctors often prescribe low-dose
aspirin, for example, particularly for patients who've
already had a heart attack and for those known to be
at high risk. And drugs that help manage risk factors, like high blood pressure, cholesterol,
and diabetes, will make heart attacks less likely, too. Heart attacks may be common, 
but they don't have to be inevitable. A healthy diet, avoiding tobacco use, staying fit, and enjoying plenty of sleep
and lots of laughter all go a long way in making sure
your body's most important muscle keeps on beating.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: All of the following can reduce the risk of heart attacks except which one?
Options: A. Regular exercise, B. Sleep deprivation, C. Low dose aspirin, D. Diabetes control
Correct Option: B

It lowers the risk of heart attacks, D. It only benefits people who have already had a heart attack Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the winter of 1995, scientists pointed the Hubble Telescope
at an area of the sky near the Big Dipper, a spot that was dark and out of the way
of light pollution from surrounding stars. The location was apparently empty,
and the whole endeavor was risky. What, if anything, was going to show up? Over ten consecutive days, the telescope took close to 150 hours
of exposure of that same area. And what came back 
was nothing short of spectacular: an image of over 1,500 distinct galaxies glimmering in a tiny sliver 
of the universe. Now, let's take a step back to understand
the scale of this image. If you were to take a ballpoint pen and hold it at arm's length 
in front of the night sky, focusing on its very tip, that is what the Hubble Telescope captured
in its first Deep Field image. In other words, those 3,000 galaxies were seen 
in just a tiny speck of the universe, approximately one two-millionth
of the night sky. To put all this in perspective, the average human measures
about 1.7 meters. With Earth's diameter 
at 12,700 kilometers, that's nearly 7.5 million humans
lined up head to toe. The Apollo 8 astronauts flew a distance
of 380,000 kilometers to the moon. And our relatively small Sun has a
diameter of about 1.4 million kilometers, or 110 times the Earth's diameter. A step further, the Milky Way holds somewhere 
between 100 to 400 billion stars, including our Sun. And each glowing dot of a galaxy captured
in the Deep Field image contains billions of stars
at the very least. Almost a decade after taking
the Deep Field image, scientists adjusted the optics
on the Hubble Telescope and took another long exposure
over a period of about four months. This time, they observed 10,000 galaxies. Half of these galaxies have since been
analyzed more clearly in what's known as 
the eXtreme Deep Field image, or XDF. By combining over ten years 
of photographs, the XDF shows galaxies so distant that they're only 
one ten-billionth the brightness that the human eye can perceive. So, what can we learn about the universe
from the Deep Field images? In a study of the universe, space and time
are inextricably linked. That's because of 
the finite speed of light. So the Deep Field images are like
time machines to the ancient universe. They reach so far into space and time that we can observe galaxies
that existed over 13 billion years ago. This means we're looking
at the universe as it was less than a billion years 
after the Big Bang, and it allows scientists to research
galaxies in their infancy. The Deep Field images have also shown
that the universe is homogeneous. That is, images taken at different
spots in the sky look similar. That's incredible when we think about
how vast the universe is. Why would we expect it to be the same
across such huge distances? On the scale of a galaxy, 
let alone the universe, we're smaller than 
we can readily comprehend, but we do have the capacity to wonder, to question, to explore, to investigate, and to imagine. So the next time you stand gazing up
at the night sky, take a moment to think about the enormity
of what is beyond your vision, out in the dark spaces between the stars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which statement below best describes the area of sky the Hubble image captured in 1995?
Options: A. The sky region was a very busy place with lots of stars., B. The sky region was known to have a lot of stars present., C. The sky region was thought to have a lot of stars present., D. The sky region was completely dark with no stars present.
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary goal of scientists when they pointed the Hubble Telescope at an area of the sky near the Big Dipper in 1995? Options: A. To study the Big Dipper, B. To capture an image of the Milky Way, C. To observe a dark and empty area of the sky, D. To study the Sun Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the outcome of the Hubble Telescope's 150 hours of exposure of the same area over ten consecutive days? Options: A. An image of the Moon, B. An image of over 1,500 distinct galaxies, C. An image of the Sun, D. An image of the Earth Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were to take a ballpoint pen and hold it at arm's length in front of the night sky, focusing on its very tip, what would it represent in relation to the Hubble Telescope's first Deep Field image? Options: A. The entire universe, B. A large portion of the night sky, C. The area captured in the first Deep Field image, D. A single galaxy Correct Option: C
Question 4: How many humans lined up head to toe would be equivalent to the Earth's diameter? Options: A. 1 million, B. 7.5 million, C. 10 million, D. 100 million Correct Option: B
Question 5: What can be inferred about the universe based on the Deep Field images showing galaxies so distant that they're only one ten-billionth the brightness that the human eye can perceive? Options: A. The universe is small and finite, B. The universe is vast and contains many galaxies, C. The universe is homogeneous and uniform, D. The universe is constantly changing Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why are the Deep Field images like "time machines to the ancient universe"? Options: A. Because they show the universe as it is today, B. Because they show the universe as it was in the past, C. Because they show the universe as it will be in the future, D. Because they show the universe in a different dimension Correct Option: B
Question 7: What have the Deep Field images shown about the universe in terms of its structure and composition? Options: A. The universe is heterogeneous and irregular, B. The universe is homogeneous and uniform, C. The universe is made up of only a few galaxies, D. The universe is constantly changing and evolving Correct Option: B
Question 8: If the Milky Way holds between 100 to 400 billion stars, and each galaxy captured in the Deep Field image contains billions of stars, what can be inferred about the total number of stars in the universe? Options: A. The total number of stars is relatively small, B. The total number of stars is in the trillions, C. The total number of stars is in the quadrillions, D. The total number of stars is infinite Correct Option: D
Question 9: How do the Deep Field images allow scientists to research galaxies in their infancy? Options: A. By showing galaxies as they are today, B. By showing galaxies as they were in the past, C. By showing galaxies as they will be in the future, D. By showing galaxies in a different dimension Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of the eXtreme Deep Field image (XDF) in relation to the Deep Field images? Options: A. The XDF is a smaller version of the Deep Field images, B. The XDF is a more detailed version of the Deep Field images, C. The XDF shows galaxies that are closer to us than the Deep Field images, D. The XDF shows galaxies that are more distant than the Deep Field images Correct Option: D

A single galaxy, we see that the transcript describes this area as a "tiny sliver of the universe" and later as "just a tiny speck of the universe, approximately one two-millionth of the night sky." **Transcript**:
In the winter of 1995, scientists pointed the Hubble Telescope
at an area of the sky near the Big Dipper, a spot that was dark and out of the way
of light pollution from surrounding stars. The location was apparently empty,
and the whole endeavor was risky. What, if anything, was going to show up? Over ten consecutive days, the telescope took close to 150 hours
of exposure of that same area. And what came back 
was nothing short of spectacular: an image of over 1,500 distinct galaxies glimmering in a tiny sliver 
of the universe. Now, let's take a step back to understand
the scale of this image. If you were to take a ballpoint pen and hold it at arm's length 
in front of the night sky, focusing on its very tip, that is what the Hubble Telescope captured
in its first Deep Field image. In other words, those 3,000 galaxies were seen 
in just a tiny speck of the universe, approximately one two-millionth
of the night sky. To put all this in perspective, the average human measures
about 1.7 meters. With Earth's diameter 
at 12,700 kilometers, that's nearly 7.5 million humans
lined up head to toe. The Apollo 8 astronauts flew a distance
of 380,000 kilometers to the moon. And our relatively small Sun has a
diameter of about 1.4 million kilometers, or 110 times the Earth's diameter. A step further, the Milky Way holds somewhere 
between 100 to 400 billion stars, including our Sun. And each glowing dot of a galaxy captured
in the Deep Field image contains billions of stars
at the very least. Almost a decade after taking
the Deep Field image, scientists adjusted the optics
on the Hubble Telescope and took another long exposure
over a period of about four months. This time, they observed 10,000 galaxies. Half of these galaxies have since been
analyzed more clearly in what's known as 
the eXtreme Deep Field image, or XDF. By combining over ten years 
of photographs, the XDF shows galaxies so distant that they're only 
one ten-billionth the brightness that the human eye can perceive. So, what can we learn about the universe
from the Deep Field images? In a study of the universe, space and time
are inextricably linked. That's because of 
the finite speed of light. So the Deep Field images are like
time machines to the ancient universe. They reach so far into space and time that we can observe galaxies
that existed over 13 billion years ago. This means we're looking
at the universe as it was less than a billion years 
after the Big Bang, and it allows scientists to research
galaxies in their infancy. The Deep Field images have also shown
that the universe is homogeneous. That is, images taken at different
spots in the sky look similar. That's incredible when we think about
how vast the universe is. Why would we expect it to be the same
across such huge distances? On the scale of a galaxy, 
let alone the universe, we're smaller than 
we can readily comprehend, but we do have the capacity to wonder, to question, to explore, to investigate, and to imagine. So the next time you stand gazing up
at the night sky, take a moment to think about the enormity
of what is beyond your vision, out in the dark spaces between the stars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many months did Hubble spend gathering the images (exposures) used to create the Hubble Deep Field image?
Options: A. 2 months, B. 4 months, C. 10 months, D. 1 year
Correct Option: B
